I watched this movie several times as a child and thought it was a cool movie. Now, a couple of years later, it's my favorite movie! It has a slow start, but you can't not love it at the end. Everyone could recognize something about themselves in these 4 kids. No matter of you're a boy or a girl. There are some memorable scenes that probably stay with you for a long, long time.This movie is simply about being a kid. After seeing this movie, you will probably miss being a kid for a while. But that's the message I personally think.The acting job of the 4 kids is amazing! Wil Wheaton and River Phoenix did an amazing job. Corey Feldman and Jerry O'Connell were also outstanding.It's also a movie you could see for like 20 times in one week and you still be excited about it! For children, this movie is just very fun. For teenagers / adults it's still a great movie, because this movie has an interesting message.I give it a 10/10

So much has been said already, but this is a movie that not only stands the test of time, but grows with you as you age. I was the same age as the characters when this came out and I thought it was a cool story about running away with your friends.
As an adult I realized it wasn't just about the death of a child named ray Brower, it was about the death of childhood and innocence. Just like the train, you can dodge it and try to escape it for a while, but eventually, time and age will hit you like a train and knock you out of your keds.
As an adult with kids, I now watch it and it hurts thinking about my own middle schoolers growing up. But the thing I never thought much about was Gordie's parents. They mourn Denny so much that they fail to recognize the great kid they still have.

I first watched this movie when I was around 11 two years ago, and I love it even more every time I watch it. "Stand by Me" is the ultimate story about friendship, and being able to trust and rely on your friends. It's main characters are four twelve year old boys; intelligent, aspiring writer Gordie (Wil Wheaton), the 'tough' leader Chris (River Phoenix), the sensitive 'but trying to hide it' Teddy (Corey Feldman) and Vern (Jerry O'Connell), the wuss of the group.The four friends, who are all facing troubles at home, group together in order to find the body of a 12 year old who was recently hit by a train and killed. However, the bad gang in town is also after the body, and so Gordie and his friends must get there first. The story is told from the perspective of an older Gordie, looking back on his childhood, and takes place over a period of 2 days. They face several adventures along the way, but it turns out that what they realise at the end of the day is how strong friendships can be.My favourite thing in this movie is the friendship between Gordie and his best friend Chris. They're two very different boys, but their friendship is so powerful and strong it is the highlight of the movie. My favourite performance in this whole movie has to be the one by the now late River Phoenix; he is incredibly natural and lights up every scene he is in. He is arguably the best actor of his generation, and would've been one of the big stars of today, had he not died so young. All of the performances, however, contribute to the enormous success that this movie is.I recommend this movie to everyone from the ages of around 11 and upwards. The only reason for it's 15/R, etc, rating is for the frequent use of bad language, especially by the four boys. It is a fantastic, refreshing movie, and reduced me to tears at the end. Very touching, highly recommended. 10/10

Review title: This classic film is worth a watch!
Review_body: This film is a brilliant, well-acted masterpiece! What touched me the most was the late River Phoenix's acting, but all of the young actors performances were incredible. They are why you should see this film. 'Stand By Me' is not a bubblegum Disney film, nor a dry Hollywood film; it is a movie that captures childhood in a poignant, non-candy coated manner that is dead on. I saw this movie only a couple months ago and was blown away by it's style and acting. It is rare that you see such fresh, relaxed and deep performances that the actors in this film offered. Although this is not a recent film, it is a genuine, inspiring film that is so refreshing-being so different than the films Hollywood often gives us. I give this film a 100+ and recommend it to everyone. You will benefit from it's message and it's wonderful acting.

Stand by me shows a time of innocence not only through the astounding acting from the four main characters but from the setting of the film and also from the soundtrack. Set in the 50's, stand by me follows four boys: Chris Chambers(River Phoenix), Geordie Lachance(Will Wheaton), Teddy Duchamp(Corey Fieldman) and Vern Tessio(Jerry O'Connel)on there journey to fine the body of a missing boy. On their way they encounter many obstacles both mentally and physical ones that bring the boys closer together. Based on the novella "The Body" by Stepehen King, Stand by me shows what true coming of age is really about, Friendship and fun. A truly magnificent film that is a definite must watch!

I've seen quite a few comments questioning why this movie is so highly rated. I remember it fondly from my childhood and re-watched it recently after seeing a spoof of it in Season 7 of the Family Guy. I didn't recall the movie being so short (though I like 1:30 movies), actually kind of boring, and an ending that doesn't make a whole lot of sense. But to answer the question about why it is liked, I suspect many of the individuals who rank this movie very highly are men and possibly were kids in the 80s. That fits my description. The 4 kids in the movie were just a couple years younger than me, though at the time they acted my age. Every kid had a group they hung out with and being 12 or so is about the most carefree time of your life. I never had an adventure quite like this, was never bullied to this extreme, but we did explore the woods, uncover cool stuff, admit our vulnerabilities, joke around, and even cry. Add in a narrator, and some cool 50s music, 4 kids you would want to hang out with (even if they would never be actual friends in real life) and you pretty much can't go wrong. Thus the 8 star rating I gave the movie. Sentimentality wins in this movie.However, in terms of actual entertainment, it falls a little short. It is interesting, sentimental, and overall a neat story that is worth watching. But it does not deserve a 9 or 10 rating in my opinion.One big question I've never seen answered anywhere is why did the kids want the body so bad? Why were they willing to be terribly beat up or even killed for it? Then willing to kill others for it. Only to then just leave it and call it in? This makes no sense. Why did the bullies not just wait and jump the kids or sneak up from behind, there were over 7 of them?!? Finally in the recap there was no mention of Kiefer's character getting revenge (thanks, Family Guy). He said this is not over, but did he just move on with his life? Did he suddenly have a religious experience and forgiveness? Did both cars crash on the way back home that day and all of them died? There's a huge hole in the end of this movie that really frustrated me to the point I almost lowered this move that was treasured in my mind down to 7 stars. Well, ultimately many movies have plot holes and the positives of this movie and the very last scene where Richard Dreyfus types the final 2 lines of his book convinced me to keep it at 8 stars so that is that.

Review title: A amazing movie still relevant at this time
Review_body: I recently started reading Stephen King books and been in love since with his stories and when I came upon this movie I had to watch it. Also Stranger Things is one of my favorite shows and I heard the two had a lot in common, what is true.This is a pretty old movie and I usually get frustrated by the bad acting and camera work when a movie is this old, this was totally not the case in this masterpiece. Especially Wil Wheaton but also all the other actors did an amazing job.The story is very Stephen King like, it is not horror but it shocks you the way only he can do it and leave you with a lot of emotions ones the movie is over. It portrays how deep friendship can go and how quickly you can lose each other again.I think this is one of the best movies I have recently seen and I will definitely starting to check out more older movies

I cannot recall a time I have ever seen a movie with a plot as simple as this that still managed to be so effective and powerful. I felt connected to the main characters of the movie who were all likeable in their own ways. The villain characters may have been shallow but that is more than made up for in the excellent acting and chemistry between the main characters. I laughed during this movie and I even cried by the end of it. This is a small gem that should not be missed out on and I'm glad I found it and gave it a chance! Stephen King really is one of the greatest storytellers of our time even when he isn't doing the horror he is most well known for.
If you're reading this then you need to watch MORE movies...starting with Stand By Me. Ultimate classic, R. I. P. River Phoenix.

One of the few few films I can watch over and over. great acting. great sound track, but was does it, is the perfect pacing of the scenes. the suspense, coupled with the relaxation of a hot summer day

Review title: Go check out the new DVD right now!!!
Review_body: Just did so myself. If you haven't seen the movie, you're in for a real treat, a truly wonderful movie.If you HAVE seen the movie, you can enjoy watching it again, of course, and re-live the days by hearing the principals talk of their memories of making the movie. Some surprises, at least for me, include: Rob Reiner and Richard Dreyfuss were friends back when they weren't much older than the kids in this movie.Jerry O'Connell was scared to death of Kiefer Sutherland, which was probably on purpose, as Jerry's character was supposed to fear Kiefer's.It was touching to hear the guys talk about River Phoenix, and amazing seeing him alive again in the music video, hamming it up with Wil Wheaton and Ben King.In other words, I enjoyed this very much!!

Review title: the most important film of my life
Review_body: When I was 7 years old, I first saw Stand By Me. I was amazed and envious of the four 12 year olds, at the fact that they fudged on their parents ("worth a hiding") to "tent out" and go see a dead body. They cussed, smoked, and thought about the 'A'and the 'E' starting to bulge on Annette's sweater (heeheehee). At the age of 7, I admired them and aspired to be 12 years old and so mature. And at 19 years old, I still do.

Review title: My fave movie of all time!!
Review_body: Ever since I was twelve, when I first saw this film, it has been a personal favorite.  I watched it over a hundred times between the ages of 12 and 15 and still break it out on a regular basis.  It makes me laugh, cry and cheer, which is really all one could ask for in one movie.

Not much to say about this, other than its a hilarious movie with many surprises and keeps you on the edge of your seat. It starts out in a fantastic setting, a small quaint town, with a group of four mischievous young boys who are always getting into trouble. As the plot line progresses, they make up an excuse and plan to set off to find a teenagers dead body. They are so interested in finding this boy because he is the same age as the boys. As they set off, many obstacles and great fears are in their way, including the sound of night, leeches and more. Though it is somewhat a horror drama, The laughs are well planned, and not cheesy whatsoever. As the obsession grows, will they give up? And what is the twist ending? Watch the movie and see!

Review title: Watch It You Wont Regret It
Review_body: i am 15 years old and i got STAND BY ME the deluxe edition about 1 week ago. And did i like it? No, I LOVED it. what an amazing movie. and yes i am a teenager so i'll say it River Pheonix is beyond hot, and i am so sad that he died. but aside from that this movie is great and has become my favorite. the actors are incredible. the 4 boys do an amazing job. Gordie is the sensitive and intelligent boy played so well by Wil Wheaton, Chris is the "bad kid" as he has been labeled but brings the peace when something is wrong played wonderfully by River Pheonix. Teddy is crazy yet sensitive, at least about his dad, played by Corey Feldman (i love the seen where he's standing guard and he wont shut up and let the other boys sleep.) And Vern the scaredy cat of the group played by Jerry O'Connel. Plus an excellent performance by Keifer Sutherland as the very mean and dangerous Ace. This movie has everything, its not too fluffy and soft that only a girl should watch it and its not way too tough that only a boy can watch. Anybody can watch this movie and fall in love with it, like i have. If you have not watched this movie Watch it you wont regret it.

Stand By Me (SBM) is as watchable today as it was 30 years ago.Casting Dreyfus as narrator was a genius move.The fact that I was "12 going on 13" in 1959 empowers me to suggest that Reiner nailed the characters' personalities--not just the 4 comrades, but also the older guys.My daughter is 25, and I'll bet we watched SBM 10 times as she was growing up.Highly recommend.
I returned to this film after 15 years and it is somehow better every time you view it. A true masterpiece

Review title: The Most Powerful Movie In The World
Review_body: Never in my life have I seen a film like this. At first it seemed unappealing: four 12-year-old boys going to find a dead body. But by the time I was at the end, I was in tears. This is such a beautiful film. It revolves around Gordie Lachance, a sensitive boy who lost his brother and feels unloved and unappreciated by his dad. So when he hears of the body, he and his three friends, Chris Chambers, Teddy Duchamp and Vern Tessio, embark on a long journey down the train tracks to find it. The one scene that drove me to tears and I can never forget is when Gordie breaks down and cries over how his dad hates him and Chris, played beautifully by River Phoenix (may he rest in peace) is there to support him and make him feel good about himself and to be honest I think this film should have had two Oscars. One for Rob Reiner's superb directing and the other for the powerful and influential performance by River Phoenix.

Review title: A masterpiece about teenage boys coming of age
Review_body: Four boys wrestle after wading through a river. A discovery of a leech makes the boys strip down to their underwear, ripping the black creatures off. Finally one boy finds a leech in his boxers. He pulls it out with bloodied fingers and faints.Situations like these come up often in Rob Reiner's Stand By Me. The film is told by a grown up Gordie Lachance (Richard Dreyfuss). It is set in the '50s about a gang of boys; a young Gordie Lachance (Wil Wheaton), Chris Chambers (River Phoenix), Teddy Duchamp (Corey Feldman), and Vern Tessio (Jerry O' Connell). The gang learn that a dead body is in the woods and camp out to find it. However the journey turns into a coming of age story. It focuses on Gordie's life: his feelings about his dead older brother and how he feels like an outsider within the gang. The film contains many exciting and unusual scenes. My personal favourites were Lardass' story and the discovery of the body.The director captures the meaning of being a kid. Also he shows the pains of growing up and accepting what we have to do in later life.

People are delusional: this was one of the worst movies I have ever seen. It stars off not bad, looks like it can go somewhere and I'll save you the two hours, it doesn't. It has sense of humor for a 5 year old, not funny to anyone semi mature. Pretty much nothing happens and nothing gets accomplished.

Feldman at the beginning of their careers. The entire cast is superb and it so perfectly paced, that the story unfolds with wit, pathos and sensitivity and completely free of emotional shortcuts.The subsequent early death of one of the young stars serves to make this story of friendship even more poignant, and the end has added extra impact.The tale itself, adapted from a Stephen King story, dwells on the mates' quest to find the body of a schoolboy supposedly struck down by a train while walking in the woods. They set off hoping to find fame, but then start to reveal their own personal secrets and the journey becomes as emotional as it is physical.It's hard to tell if the four young actors are all geniuses or just perfectly cast, but the performances are never short of real, and if some of the key scenes don't have you choking back tears, you are without a soul.

This movie introduced me to the works of Stephen King. Before this I had thought he only wrote horror. I saw this movie and I realized he was a much broader author than I had given him credit for.Wil Wheaton should have won an award for his portryal of Gordie LaChance. He genuinely gets into the part and it shows. The scene where he cries and puts his head on River Phoenix's shoulder actually brought tears to my eyes. It's too bad that he didn't do much after he left Star Trek: The Next Generation.All in all I gave this movie a 10/10.

Review title: One of the most amazing Stephen King movies ever filmed.
Review_body: The movie is one of the greatest movies that I have ever seen. It's one of the movies that will touch you deep into your heart. It's what makes a movie amazing. The kids did an amazing job of acting out the characters of Teddy, Vern, Chris, and Gordie. It is an deep and does an an amazing job of reanacting the novella. The plot is amazing. It's the summer that every kid has to have. The one where the only thing that matters is being with your friends and having fun. Before everything else sets in. It tells of four best friends with all messed up family life's which mostly all they have is each other. Most definitely one of my favorite movies ever. It follows the boys as they journey to find something that will either make them or break them. What they are searching for is something that will make them local hero's. I thought that book was greatly amazing as the book. Stephen King did an excellent job on his part. But he never ceases to fail in my book. The cast was well chosen out for each part. Especially River for Chirs, and Corey Feldman for Teddy. They both did an amazing job adapting to there characters. This goes above and beyond of movies that friendship movies that go deep. Absolutely amazing.

Review title: A dynamic horizon of friendship, loss and memory!
Review_body: This really does atone for all the films that attempt to compress ideas of friendship, loss, bitterness and isolation together, because no film does it like Stand By Me. This film, although made in 1986 (i say this because of the amazing enhancements in technology in the past decade)chills me, and i cannot help taking a moment after the film's completion to regain a sense of bliss about the world. Because Stand By Me poses many questions about one's self- Who really are my mates? Are they worth living for? Are they worth dying for? And as River Phoenix portrays (brilliant actor) some things in the world are worth risking for, as his character fades into the winds of memory. I cannot help feel a sense of bereavement for River, seven years after the film, his character really does evaporate and it will be ten years this october (2003) since his death. Facing the dawn of youth, this film about four inquisitive kids grasps the inspiration they find in each other to carry on and live for each other- no matter what their parents think of them, they have three other mates that will make them laugh when things are bad, revamp their spirit when all is lost and make them cry because these times cannot last forever.

This has always been, and will always be, my favorite movie of all time. I've grown up with this movie, and it has influenced me to become a screenwriter.  I only hope that I can someday write something that is as good, and affecting as this film.  It has the best performances by a young cast in the history of cinema.  In addition, it has just the right blend of comedy and drama.  How can you not love this movie?

Stand By Me is the story of four adolescent boys who venture out of their small Oregon town in search of a boy who has disappeared and feared dead. Only two people know where he really is. When word reaches these boys, the race is on to find him.The leader of this crew is Chris Chambers (River Phoenix), a strong willed individual who carries a bum rap. Gordie Lachance (Will Wheaton) idolized Chris and everything he does. Gordie has been the "other child" at home since his brother died. The headstrong Teddy Duchamp (Corey Feldman) is the renegade "wild-man" whose war weary father has made a strong impact on, for better and for worse. The last of this "gang" is Vern Tessio (Jerry O'Connell), the one who found out about the resting place of the lost boy. Vern is slightly overweight and jittery; the tag-a-long friend.Narrated by an older Gordie (Richard Dreyfuss), now a writer, we see the characters through his eyes essentially, even though it isn't just about Gordie, but all of them. Reiner's casting is superb for all four friends and even the older kids. The leader of the older kids is Ace Merrill (Kiefer Sutherland), a dark and menacing character who strikes fear into the hearts of the four boys. It is his presence that makes the boys more determined than ever to find the body before he does The next two days for these boys is filled with obstacles, both on the tough Oregon landscape and in their troubled minds. It seems like they live their entire childhood and adolescent years in a span shorter than 48 hours. Usually a person experiences certain things one at a time over a long period of time. It seems that no matter where these boys go in life, they will never forget those two days when they were no long children, but men.

There are quite a few films that are completely classified as a family film. I almost was astonish to gaze the acting of little kids that i momentarily thought they are lot better than the grown up actors in the film. I honestly can remember the first time I saw this movie...it was at my grandmother's house sometime before Christmas of 1989. I remember sitting in front of her new TV with her new VCR and watching this movie with all of my cousins; it's funny because this was one of the last times that I had the pleasure of doing so. I was one of the middle grandchildren for my grandparents, and had a lot of cousins that were substantially older than me, so I did a lot of looking up towards them. Seeing this movie put a lot of things into perspective for me, and looking back on it, it was almost a time when things were much more simple. I will always cherish this movie and the memories that I can associate with it for as long as I'll live.

Stand By Me is one of those movies which in the end leaves you with some tears in your eyes. Its excellent plot and acting makes this movie perfect, although I would not call this the greatest movie ever made I definitely think it deserves a better rating than 8,1. Its another movie where somebody retells a part of his life, usually these kinds of movies can either turn into a disaster or masterpiece. Gordie Lachance played by Wil Wheaton is a boy who lives in a small town, hes in a gang with three others, his best friend Chris Chambers who comes from a bad family, the crazy Teddy Duchamp and the last one in the gang Vern Tessio. All four have some trouble in their families. One day Vern tells the gang about a dead body in a forest outside of town, and they decide to try to find this body. I wont tell you more of the plot, but I can say it is just magnificent, and in the end it just leaves a mark in your heart. The detailed but short plot makes you feel like one of them and makes you wish the movies tragic ending wont end. Its a great masterpiece, as most of the great movies out there Stand By Me is based on Stephen Kings novel The Body.I really recommend this movie to anyone, it is very emotional, it has a great plot combined with the excellent acting. This movie deserves a better rating than it already has.

A childhood classic that still holds up today. Every scene in this film brings up a new memory for my younger days. For every character in the film I image a friend I had growing up and how similar they are to them. The ending is sad, but there are plenty of laughs and good times to be had along the way. The pie eating scene, the leach scene, the dog scene, the dead body scene. I remember talking about all of them for hours with my friend as a kid. Even though we all saw the film we'd stand around or sit around and talk about it and describe it to each other like we'd never seen it before. I have a friend that died and friends that I haven't seen in ages and when I re-watched this movie memories of them ran through my head. It made me sad and happy both at the same time. I don't have kids, but if I did this is a movie I would love to share with them. If you haven't seen it please do and if you have seen it, watch it again because it stands the test of time.

Stand by Me adapted from the 1981 novella, written by Stephen King, The Body, is a allegory for any person that wants to spend the last weekend with their chums and engage on an odyssey that demonstrates honesty and aspiration. The nexus between the four main friends is both kind and noble. The way the film's narrator, who is played by legendary film actor Richard Dryffus (apologize for any misspelled words and erroneous grammar)who plays one of the young boys grown up as a writer, and how he sees in the beginning of the film those two boys on the bike allows him to reflect on his childhood and how friendship is eternal. The last ten minutes of the film, for me, are the most memorable and emotional when Chris Chanmbers, played by the late River Phoenix, is described by Richard Dryfus as being killed to try to settle a dispute, which reflects Mr. Chambers kind and conciliatory character, which was greatly accentuated by Mr. Phoenix understanding and passionate role. Thank you to Rob Reiner, Stephen King and the entire cast and filmmakers working on the film.

It's one of those films that after watching; you can't stop thinking about for days. To cut it short, the cast did a great job on this. The film displays a lot of emotion, which I like. Just like how some horror movies have comedy in, and some comedy have horror in. This had multiple genres that you could squeeze into it's description; the sadness of the dead body - a poor kid who got hit by a train. The humorous jokes and lifestyle of the teens - The love shown to Gordie's deceased brother - and more.The story is different. I liked that the director(s) used children to portray the characters, and that Stephen King used memories of his childhood to piece this film together. It makes the film mean a lot more.
An amazing coming of age story about 4 boys, however it's not just a boys movie! It's hilarious, honest, and pure. All around fantastic piece of cinema.

Friends stand by friends, no matter what. No matter what the circumstances or afraid they might be, friends stand by friends. The basis of the film Stand by Me is exactly that.Stand by Me is about four middle school friends who spend all of their time together. But when the chubby lovable one Vern (Jerry O'Connell) says, "Do you guys wanna see a dead body?" Vern then proceeds to inform the group about how he overheard his older brother and a friend discussing the whereabouts of a dead body. Now this dead body was a classmate of the boys and they thought that if they were the ones to find the body, then they would be famous. So the boys set out on an two day adventure to find the body.One of the main characters named Gordie Lachance (Wil Wheaton) is the average, younger brother of the star athlete of the town and feels the scrutiny of the town especially by his father after his brother passes. He feels like he means nothing and is unimportant. But this is where friends step in. His best friend, Chris Chambers (River Phoenix), tells him that he is going to be writer and very famous some day. The bond between these two is unbreakable to the end.Stand by Me is a story based off of the novella The Body by Stephen King and is narrated throughout the duration of the story.Rob Riener directed this film and did an amazing job. He brought out the true emotions of these kids. The young boys also displayed a tremendous acting ability and carried this movie to another level. The viewer could really feel the bond and the love between the boys in this story.Overall, Stand by Me was a fantastic film that should be watched by any adolescent. It is a coming of age film and one of the best of its genre. This film is extremely entertaining and highly recommended.
The writing, the variety of characters, the issues they handle and the range of kinds of comedy is all on point. You are missing out if you haven't seen this.

Review title: The greatest movie of all time...
Review_body:
This has to be, all around, the greatest movie I have ever seen. It is right up there with THE GODFATHER, CASINO and THE STAND. The acting, all of it, was the best I've seen in a while, especially that of River Phoenix.
This film, based on the novella DIFFERENT SEASONS by Stephen King, has it all, I mean the acting, writing directing and editing are top notch.I was extremely impressed with the serious issues the film delt with, yet still managed to have some very funny parts in it. Review title: The best film of all time
Review_body: Every now and then, a movie comes along that you carry in you heart forever. I first saw this movie when I was about seven. After several years had passed, I rented it again, and could not believe what I saw on the screen. It was this perfect movie, the actors were brilliant as was the writing and directing. I was about the same age as the characters, and I related to their feelings and emotions. It had parts that made me laugh (the campfire scene), parts that made me cry (the milk money scene) and parts I will never forget ( "I'll see you around." "Not if I see you first."). This movie touched my heart like no other movie has before. It is THE coming-of-age movie. No one has made a better one, and I don't think they ever will.

After Stephen King was asked by his publisher to write a 'non-supernatural' book, he initially refused. As he got used to the idea, he wrote a 4-novella's containing masterpiece, including 'Stand by me'. It's a genuine masterpiece telling of early teenager's chains of thoughts and displays realistically the fears, anxieties and all other important issues in 12-year old boy's minds. 'Stand by me' has a fantastic cast of, among others, Kiefer Sutherland and River Phoenix. The original title of the story, 'The body', was renamed 'Stand by me' after the title song, which occurs throughout the whole film in various adaptions and reflects the specific moods of the moment. I have seen this film in a time-span of about 8 years about 10 times. It seems crazy, but it's the truth. The film is perfect in all its aspects: beginning, plot, characters, '2nd level', and even ending (not one of King's strong points).The  film contains no gore, blood, monsters or non-realistic elements as we're used to of King, but is, next to 'The Shawshank Redemption', his best movie. The movie definitely earns his spot in the IMDB top-250.

Even though I wasn't alive during the 1950's, I got a good idea how life was watching Stand By Me, based on the novella of Stephen King. Your friends were everything; you played games together, hiked together, told scary stories, and went on long ventures. While this is true today, you didn't have life's many pleasures such as video games, or computers. Things were different back then...The movie tells the story of four young boys who go on a trek through the Oregon Wilderness in search of a dead body, but find much more than that..The acting you get from the four young boys is incredible, as is the directing by Reiner who stuck to the nitty-gritty of King's story. The movie itself is filled with memorable one-liners (Annette's cleavage),  stories (Lard Ass),  and scenes (the Leeches).This is the ultimate growing-up movie. We witness the last days of kids being kids, and their moving up to adulthood. But this movie isn't all that sappy. It is humorous, dramatic,  up-lifting, and serious.One I would wholly recommend.

As many other people who have seen this film will agree. There aren't many films which draw multiple emotions from a person but Stand by Me is one of them. This films' power of nostalgia is immense, and if you can tell me, after watching it, that this film means nothing to you then your missing a big part of life's experiences.

Review title: The best movie of all time.
Review_body: I'm going to start by saying that I think that this is the best movie of all time. I'm Wil Wheaton's (Gordie) # 1 fan and have seen most of his movies. Stand by me is certainly one of the best films I have ever seen. It's a great film, but not only because it's very dramatic. In fact the story that it tells is a great story, that make a great film. It isn't only the story of four boys who are searching the body of a missing boy, but also an important portrait of a genuinely and authentic friendship in 1950's USA. It bind four boys, all in a very abandoned and pitiable condition. No affect. Only this friendship. So, the boys try to find affect in their friends. All need affect but we see especially Gordie. He's the protagonist, a very sensitive boys, who first had a brother who make him happy, then (now), after the death of his brother, he hasn't anyone except his best friends Chris. Chris is abandoned. He hasn't anyone too except his best friend Gordie. I almost think that the research of the body is only the occasion to tell about this extraordinary genuine friendship. Great performance by the cast, finely choice score and good direction add to this film what make it a film you can't miss.

I first saw this movie the summer of my 11th year. I am now 30. I have seen this movie 1054 times during that time. I know it word for word.When I first saw the movie, I just loved it because the boys were so cute and the story good. Now, like so many, I look back, just like Gordy, and man I lived it! I had such adventures with the group of friends from that period of my life! I was a tomboy, so most of my friends were guys. The things we did! The stories I can tell! have told. There was Ken, my best friend, Rob, Paul, Andy, Lori, and me.Sadly, like the guys in the movie, over the years we faded away. Lori got married early, Rob became a religious recluse,Andy was in the Marines stationed in Germany last I knew. I saw Paul once years ago,he wasn't the same guy I knew. Then, Ken. Ken was killed in a car accident 2 years ago in January. He was out celebrating anew job with his brother and a friend. I hadn't seen him in three months. I miss him. We had been best friends for 13 years. So when I miss him to much, I watch this movie again. Its my favorite movie.

Review title: what coming of age movies is all about, and in the best way possible
Review_body: Rob Reiner came this close to a masterpiece only once more ("The Princess Bride")Steven King showed he can write a powerful story without having to scare us silly, and a group of young actors came up with a performance of a life time. In fact some of them were haunted by their roll in this movie straight out of a career. It's one of those magic moments when everything comes together exactly right, growing up pains and the effects death has on life rarely found a better expression in a movie or anywhere else. I could go on and on but I don't think there's any call for this, even if I don't meet the required minimal text. This is a go see movie if there ever was 1.

Review title: Stand By Me...the greatest movie of all time...that about sums it up
Review_body: I first saw Stand By Me when I was 6 years old. I never reallyunderstood it then, but the story of 4 boys (Chris, Gordie, Teddyand Vern) who go on an adventure to find a dead boy's body justkind of stuck with me. I've seen it a few more times and I know nomatter how many times I see it, I will always love it and NEVER getsick of it. In my opinion it's the best movie ever made. Everythingabout it is amazing. The actors, River Phoenix, Wil Wheaton, JerryO'Connell and Corey Feldman do an amazing job portraying theircharacters. Especially River Phoenix. I think he did the best job ofall. Stand By Me almost makes you feel like you're in the moviebecause it's so realistic. The scenery is beautiful. I love the partwhen they have to cross the bridge of train tracks. There's a verygood view there. Some people may think Stand By Me soundsboring, but there's not one boring scene in the movie. Thedialogue is exceptional and you'll probably want to rewind at somepoint to hear a certain line again. I read the book which the moviewas based on and i was so amazed at how the movie stayed trueto the characters and everything else. I can't say ANYTHING bad about the movie, except the pukescene was very gross. (i hope that's not a spoiler) But i guess itwent well with the story line considering the characters were 412-year-old boys. So, all i can say is if you haven't seen it, you've got to becauseeveryone i know who's seen it, loves it. Sincerely! (quote fromVern!) So go rent it, buy it, or for all i care, go steal it from a friend!just go see it!

Review title: You will never have friends like you had when u were 11
Review_body: This movie is one of the best movies I have ever seen & perhaps one ever made. You can easily connect with the movie, the characters & incidents that take place in this movie.Even though it is a cult American childhood movie this will appeal to people all over the world who enjoyed their childhood. I do remember the little adventures we used to have back then in a small town in India with similar friends. We used to hiking in a nearby mountain & I still cant forget those days. I am not going to comment anything on the plot/story because its such a classic & I might not do justice trying to capture the magic the movie creates in mere words. This movie has left a ever lasting impression on me & takes me back to those golden days each time I watch it(already seen 4 times!!!) This one will always remain as one of my top movies.

This is my favourite movie of all time, I have lost count of how many times I have seen it. There is magic in this movie you never ever get bored of it! If you didn't see it I recommend it! Just The Best, The Greatest...

Review title: There has never been a movie better.
Review_body: For everyone in the world, who hasn't seen stand by me, let me be the first to tell you that you are missing out on something magnificent. It partly comes from the fact that i am 13 years old, and so i can really relate to what the characters are going through in this movie. There is nothing more sacred than the friendship of children. I can relate to this movie because of how Stephen King, and Rob Reiner had there characters act. Most movies with children portray them is goodie two shoes, who do whatever they are told. This movie has the four 12 year old boys, cussing, smoking, playing poker, and breaking all the rules.The movie stand by me is about four 12 year old boys. The sissy of the four, Vern (played by Jerry O'Connel) is underneath his porch searching for pennies that he had buried some time ago, when he overhears his brother, and his brother's friend talking about how they had passed the body of a dead boy, Ray Brauer. He than tells his gang about the conversation he overheard. The gang is made up of tough leader Chris (R.I.P.River Phoenix), main character Gordie (Wil Weaton), and crazy boy Teddy (Corey Feldman), all of which were cast perfectly although they in real life are a couple years older than the age they are playing.They than go on a quest to find the dead body and turn him so they can be heroes of their small town of Castle Rock, Oregon. However, Vern's brother's gang lead by Ace (Keifer Sutherland), is also on there way to becoming famous. It is a fabulous coming of age tale, with such memorable scenes as the leaches, the junkyard, and Gordies story. It is a movie NOT to miss.

Review title: Deserves to be in top 250 as long as film making exists on Earth
Review_body: First of all I would like to say I'm not the best of film critics out there and what I wanted to say about this film has already been said through the other fantastic posts on here. I just want to repeat it myself, echo my borrowed thoughts through the tool of writing. Let people know how great this film is from my own view.The film is about four friends who share the emotions, trials and tribulations of growing up, through a decision to go on a trek and find the body of a missing child of a similar age to them. This film makes you so feel so much (without giving too much away).Although I have seen a few films on TV, I usually change the channel half way through. On one particular day last year I was flicking through like I do, half blankly staring at the screen, when I came across this film. I sat and down and watched it to the end, a rare accomplishment for me.From my own opinion, films can never really evoke real life. Some films can, fair enough, but what hit me most about this film was how the ending could fit into real life. The ending was so ordinary. There was no fairytale element to this film whatsoever. Thats what made this film so feel-good for me.I have seen the films My girl, Casablanca, Titanic and The Shawshank Redemption (all brilliant films which I have also taken the care to watch). They have never even brought a lump to my throat. The ending to Stand By Me was so personally heart-felt, however, I was not ready for the emotion that would overwhelm me. A personal experience that has changed who I am.Definitely one of my top 3 films for life.

Review title: A Perfect Trigger and Gateway to Memory Lane
Review_body: I haven't expected too much from the movie at the very beginning. I thought it was just another 80's generational movie which will not resonate too much with me. I was utterly wrong because Stand By Me proved to be a perfect trigger and gateway to memory lane. It reminded me of the famous madeleine episode in Swann's Way, Marcel Proust's novel. The novel narrator eats madeleines dunked in tea which helps him recall certain past events by triggering his involuntary memory.The film opens with a sequence where the narrator (Richard Dreyfus) sits in a car shocked by the newspaper title of a lawyer's violent death as two kids pass by his car on bikes. The plot then turns into a childhood story, when the narrator and his friends, went to find a dead boy's body in the woods. One of the friends in the company was the earlier mentioned killed lawyer with whom he had a great relationship as a kid. Moreover, he helped him raise his self-esteem and bring back his confidence on numerous occasions.I liked the characters in the film because it perfectly depicts boys in every junior high school company. Gordie (Will Wheaton) is a smart but insecure, invisible boy. On the other hand, Chris (River Phoenix) is a rebellious, intelligent kid who has the potential to become good at anything if he could only have a good role model. Teddy Duchamp (Corey Feldman) is an ill-tempered, self-destructive, romantic kid. Finally, Vern (Jerry O'Connell) is that bothering kid who desperately wants to be a part of the group but isn't cool enough for that.This film was fun to watch since it served as a trigger to remember people, places, activities, and games I played as a child. I was also doing a lot of stuff with kids from my hometown that I don't have any contact with whatsoever. At the time, those kids were my best friends, and numerous great memories were waiting inside of me to get back on the surface again. I love the magic of film that can make such things happen.

This is one of the most sentimental and ironic movies I've ever watched. We all know what happened to River Phoenix's character in the movie. It's ironic that he's death was a tragedy. Every time when I watch the ending where Chris chambers fades out, it reminds me of River phoenix. 8/10

Growing up, this was the "family movie" in my house.  Meaning, it was a movie I grew up watching over and over again.  As I grew older I was able to learn more from it, and this movie transcends so much about life, and about friendship, that the full impact it had on me cannot be realized until now, as I sit here as an adult.No other movie has ever been so honest about the importance of friendship, and the reality of "drifting apart" and the ever present vulnerability of mortality that everyone endures in real life.This is a coming of age movie that defines the genre in my opinion.4 best friends leave on an innocent boyhood quest to achieve heroism, and at least 2 of the boys (Gordon and Chris) learn much about life through eachother and their friends (Vern and Teddy) that they return without their innocence, and see the world around them as much more mature individuals.If you haven't seen this movie, you have been robbed of one of the greatest stories ever told.By far my favorite movie of all time.10/10
