Review title: Stand By Me Stands the Test of Time
Review_body: Still one of the best coming-of-age movies I've even seen. Just finished rewatching it this past weekend. It's been decades since I first viewed it in theaters. I enjoyed it the first time I saw it and I enjoyed it even more this time. Standout performances by River Phoenix and Corey Feldman. Wonderful direction by Rob Reiner. And the Ben E. King version of "Stand By Me" just gets better and better with each passing year, especially the violin solo.

At first thought, this movie looked to be a repeat of The Goonies (another absolutely fabulous movie, I might add) they both starred Corey Feldman, who, in both titles played an eccentric, slightly loopy but fun character. They also both starred a gang going off on an adventure. The Goonies, after treasure, this gang, after a dead body.You have River Phoenix as Chris Chambers, a young teenager from the infamous Chambers family, famed for being criminals & hooligans. He is the brother of "Eyeball" Chambers. Chambers is an amazing character, mainly for the way he could pick on people but chooses to be friendly and always looks for the peaceful way out of things, but is a brave boy.Wil Wheaton plays Gordy, a confused chap who seems sad because his older brother died and his parents dislike his friends and seem to completely forget all about poor Gordy. Vern, played by the talented Jerry O'Connell is a bumbling but funny eleven year old school boy. He's terrified of ghosts and all, but is a great companion during the adventure. He's often the victim to the pranks of Teddy LaChance (Corey Feldman).This movie is probably the only film that I've ever watched that I would absolutely score a perfect ten, sincerely. (Pun intended.) The young cast of boys played their roles with such charisma and passion, I have honestly rarely seen such a splendid act of characters. To me, River Phoenix will forever be Chris Chambers, Wil Wheaton will always be Gordy, etc. The story is stunning. Absolutely. They all go on a journey to find a dead body, a 30 mile walk which takes them two long days. A large trek, I might add. They not only discover what they were looking for in the end, but they truly discovered the meaning of friendship.It was a soul-searching journey for themselves. It was just amazing. You also get to hear the great song "Rollercoaster" by none other than Buck Holly. So, we've got a heart warming cast of characters, engrossing story and, well... Buck Holly. This is the greatest movie that I've ever seen. And the ending was also classy and not cheesy at all."I never had friends again like the ones I had when I was 12. Jesus, does anyone?"That final line just closed the movie for me. I had that butterfly feeling in my stomach and I felt genuinely happy. Watch this movie. Buy it. Rent it. Just see it, at least once. It's an enthralling thrill ride from start to finish that every person should get to watch.I'm just happy that it graced my television screen, even if it was only for an hour and a half.

Review title: Books into movies...some times they work some times they don't but Stephen King always works
Review_body: I've seen this movie many times but still love it as much as I did 30 years ago!! Stephen King writes awesome stories which turn into awesome movies for the most part. This movie about boyhood friends who decide to become heroes by finding the body of a boy hit by train. As they travel they learn the true bonds of friendship. I love the soundtrack and the fact that Richard Dreyfuss narrates is a plus! It stars most of 80s-early 90s crushes. River Phoenix and Wil Wheaton are wonderful as Chris(Phoenix) and Gordie(Wheaton). I loved Corey Feldman's Teddy and even overweight,naive Verne(Jerry O'Connell before his days as a slim cutie Derek from Scream 2). Keifer Sutherland always made a great bad boy and of course that made him more attractive in this. My favorite character through the whole film has to be Gordie's deceased brother Denny played by John Cusack. I have this movie on a 2-disc set DVD set but I still have it on my DVR for easy viewing access. If you enjoy coming of age movies or Stephen King I really believe you'll enjoy this.

First off I'm just putting it out there. This is my favourite movie of all time :)I love the innocence of the boys who think they are tough and can handle an adventure to see a dead body. Takes guts or at least stupidity and ignorance. As all groups of friends seem to have a leader, it seemed fitting that the smartest and the toughest, Chris got the spot. It was great to see both sides to all 4 boys. they each had their tough outside demeanour but on the inside they were all as damaged as the other. -maybe not vern as much hahaWhat makes the movie stand out as a 'Great' is that is deals with an important issue all the while showcasing the true meaning of friendship. Although i love romantic movies one of the better things about this movie is that it doesn't deal with all the dramas of girls and relationships instead it focuses on a group of friends in their youth before girls became the most important things in their life.I personally recommend this movie to everyone who has taste. (my sister hates the movie but thats because she wouldn't know a good movie if it hit her in the face) Trust me... 'Stand By Me' is one of the best movies you will see :)

Review title: The best coming of age film you will ever see
Review_body: When i first saw the title i mistook it for a romantic film but it is not. It is a coming of age drama. As it is featured in IMDb's top 250 i had a lot expectations from it. And in the end it topped those expectations. It is such a movie which everyone is compelled to like. I've seen this film 25 years after its initial release yet i've liked it so it is fair to say the appeal of this film stands tall to the test of time. Maybe the reason behind is that the main theme of the film is something which everyone relates to. It is Friendship. Maybe because of this reason you always feel deeply engrossed in this tale of friendship. That is why there is not even a single dull moment in the whole movie unlike many other highly acclaimed movies.The story is rather simple maybe way too simple. But it is the execution, the genuine acting of the whole cast makes this movie such a delight to watch. I loved john Cusack who has a supporting role in the movie. His role as Gordon's brother is really well crafted though it is really short. Writing review about this movie and not mentioning River Phoenix would be injustice it is his role as the born leader of the group that gives this simple movie incredible depth.So to summarize the movie is pretty good. Highly recommended and easily re-watchable. You will love every bit of the movie.A very enthusiastic 8/10.

Review title: 'Stand by Me' is an amazing movie and a classic.
Review_body: The movie 'Stand by Me' (Rob Reiner) is coming of age film about four young boys. Throughout the film, they undergo many challenges and come to conclusions about their hometown, the world and themselves. All the boys are very different; there is at least one trait within each of the boys that everyone can relate to. This movie has a perfect combination of seriousness and the more immature and fun ways of youth. The characters deal with normal problems at the age of twelve as well as other problems like dealing with death, bad reputations and local myths. Some of the things they learn are discovered in a comical way and they learn the difference between myth and reality. The script is based on the novel "The Body" by Stephen King. Reiner closely follows the book but adds things here and there that make it much more exciting and relatable. The script is clever and well written. This movie is funny, emotional, suspenseful and a must see.

Review title: A "coming of age" movie about 12 year old boys which is NOT suitable for kids!!
Review_body: I am in my 40's and have never seen this movie, so I decided to watch it. I have a 12 year old son, and was thinking of letting him see it! I have to say that I was SHOCKED by the explicit language!! And, because of that, I will not let him see it. Do 12 year olds really talk this way? God help us if that is true! My son sure doesn't (at least around me).Other than the profanity, and overall disgusting language from minors... the movie was very well-acted, and thought-provoking. I only wish they had left out all the bad language & I would have enjoyed it more, and even watched it with my son. Sigh.... call me an "old fashioned Mother"!One other thing, don't let the cover picture fool you... this is NOT a kids movie!! It is R rated (which I believe is due to the language). Just to warn you parents out there who are thinking of letting their kids watch it.

When I first watched this movie, I was really young and thought this movie was just like all the other movies. It was a while until I found the true meaning of this movie. I love coming-of-age films because they just warm my heart. This movie has such emotions in it that i can barely ever say for any other movie. WONDERFUL cast, WONDERFUL writing, and WONDERFUL directing. I have to say the two people that really stole the show for me was River Phoenix and Kiefer Sutherland. They play their characters so well, and you really sometimes can relate to what they are saying. The chemistry between the two characters is PHENOMENAL. I wouldn't have any body else to play those two characters than the boys who preformed it. They were so young and it was still early in both of their careers. If I hadn't known that up front, I would have said that they had been acting for years. Again, amazing movie and it moved me to tears.

Review title: One of my very favorite movies
Review_body: In my opinion this is one of, if not the, best adaptations of King's work. Usually lost in terrible acting, low budget, or poor screenplay his work is usually not translated very well. This movie is well written, has excellent character actors and is one of my favorite movies. "The Body" is an excellent novella which if you enjoy the film as much as I did, I highly recommend reading it. The transportation of 4 childhood friends from innocence to realizing what happens in the rest of the world is wonderfully captured in this movie. The actors used for the parts were almost as I imagined them whilst reading the novella. Overall if you want to see an excellent film, watch this movie.

I have to say, I really enjoyed this movie. I've watched it so many times now. I can see it being a timeless movie that you could watch over and over without getting bored.This is one of the best adaptations of a Stephen King book in my opinion...and I am a huge fan of Stephen King. He's had many of his books made into movies. Examples would be 'The Shining' and 'Carrie'. It is a great story that is put across very well by some great actors. The late River Phoenix's performance as Chris Chambers was the highlight for me. And of course, Corey Feldman did his character Teddy justice.The story takes place in 1959. It centres around four young friends that set out to find the body of a boy who was killed by a train. We as viewers see their entire journey and are taken along with them. We meet another group of friends, who are not so nice. These 'bullies' are also setting out to find the body, with both groups looking to find fame by recovering the body.This movie reminds us of how important friends are and how friendships can be put to the test. I would definitely recommend this movie. It is a must see!

I'm from Japan and I love this movie.Four young people who are friends with each other set out for adventure in order to look for a missing body.WIll Wheaton plays Gordie Lanchance. He stood out as an actor in stand by me but he has almost only appeared on TV dramas since then. River Phoenix played Chris Chambers. His death, because of taking so many drugs, was surprising. its too bad. Jerry O'connell played Vern Tessio. Since then He has become thin and looks handsome. Kiefer Sutherland plays Ace Merrill. I didn't realize Kiefer Sutherland was in this movie until checking IMDb.This movie is not only funny and exciting but also recalls something like our childhood memories.I think this movie is suitable for men of more than eighteen years old because women don't so much experience such adventures.I hardly watch real life drama movies and I usually don't like such movies. however this film makes me recall my own childhood so I watch it over and over again.This movie contains unique phrases in English. For example Gordie says "piss up a rope" This word is said with resignation. I also like "walking talking Jesus".my favorite expression in the movie is "two for flinching" this expresses a punishment because of getting scared. that is why Vern Tessio is hit by Teddy Duchamp, over and over again.i love this movie i think it is as good a movie as I have ever watched.

Review title: A beautifully acted, amazing adaption of Stephen Kings novel 'The Body'.
Review_body: One of the most amazing films I have ever seen. The acting by the four boys is incredible, in particular Wil Wheaton and River Phoenix.Directed by Rob Reiner 'Stand By Me' is a funny heart warming story of four best friends with very different family backgrounds who go on a journey to find the body of a kid who had been missing but never found. The boys figure if they find the body it might bring them fame and fortune and may help them to escape their dreary lives in Castle Rock.Along the way the boys discover things about themselves and realise they aren't as strong as they thought, and maybe finding a kids dead body isn't exactly going to be the trip of a life time that they had had in mind. 'Stand By Me' is a film I couldn't fault in any way and the sound track is just as good. A must see film and one the best I have ever seen.

Review title: One of the most emotional movies ever
Review_body: For starters, I hate oldies. Music earlier than 1970, with a few exceptions like The Beatles, is just crap to me. But, because of this movie, every time I hear the song, "Stand By Me" I just have to listen to it. This has to be one of my favorite movies and will always be one of my favorites movies. Maybe because I, myself, had three really close friends when I was that age. It's now about seven years later, and none of us hang out anymore. I didn't think much of it at first, but after seeing this movie, I realized how much I liked them and how much fun we had. Also, after seeing this movie, I realized how sad it actually made me to know that I may never see them again because we're all going to different colleges. That's how powerful this movie is. And in the end, he realizes they were the best friends he's ever had. The acting and story is absolutely amazing. They really show how good of friends these kids are and how time and different situations in their lives can just tear them apart. I have never cried at a movie, and this is no exception. But it has brought me the closest to it. 10/10 Stephen King is a genius.

(Reviewed on Anniversary blu-ray) This is a tale that you will never forget, a story of childhood friendships that I am sure allot of people can relate to.I have to first of all point out that the acting in this movie is absolutely terrific! You end up with a feeling of closeness to this band of four friends while at the same time really building a resentment towards the group of older good for nothings(with Kiefer Sutherland playing a fantastic bad guy). River Phoenix, for me, was the most outstanding actor in this movie, at times it was really hard to believe how mature his acting style was.The movie is also shot very well with Rob Reiner doing a brilliant job of shooting every scene so that you are drawn into the action and really feel that you are along with the characters on a great journey both physically and emotionally. The back drop to this whole movie is also visually stunning.Without going too much into the story as to spoil it, you can expect moments of action, suspense, heart warming stories and characters you will fall in love with, this movie does not have a boring moment in it, and even though the ending ties up the story absolutely perfectly I always find myself at the end of this movie wanting it to go on and never end. I also found it made me reflect on my own childhood friends and the adventures I had with them, which was a nice thing for a movie to do.If you have a chance to watch this movie you should not pass it up! Its one you will never forget!

I taped the film some weeks ago & finally got around to watching it. I thought the story line was good; maybe because I could identify the four boys with my own childhood at that age before girls came into the picture. The acting was good although at times I missed the dialog & had to reverse the tape to "catch" what the boys said. My only criticism was that expressions were used that were more contemporary than the 50's, and I find it hard to believe that twelve year old living in the early 50's used so many four lettered words.In any case, it is a good film; down to earth; excitement particularly the "train scenes" and a picture of North American Life in the 50's. The music was tops!

Review title: Rob Reiner know's how to adapt Stephen King's greatest novels
Review_body: ---SPOILER REVIEW---- As I start to commence into the greatest hits of Stephen King, I can't say I've actually read "The Body" (Novelization of Stand By Me) However I have read Misery, and Rob Reiner obviously knows what he's doing with his source material. Stand By Me is about a journey of four boys of junior high age. What they intended on their journey wasn't the life changing revelations that succumbed in the events of the movies, but simply to find a dead body, bring it in and hopefully attain fame from it. Gordie, Chambers, Teddy and Vern, each fill their own role in the gang. Gordie is the protagonist of the story, and his revelation revolves around the death of his seemingly perfect brother, Denny, who's always supported Gordie no matter the judgment of his father, who's only ever cherished the accomplishments of Denny, while sweeping Gordie under the rug. There is a moment in the middle of the movie where Gordie is having a dream of his brothers funeral. Everyone is looking down at Denny's grave. Gordie's father puts his hand on Gordie's shoulder saying "It should've been you." Now I wasn't sure if this was actually what happened during the funeral, but Gordie wakes up directly after this, explaining to Chris(Chamber) that he didn't cry at his brother's funeral. This is presumably to point out the fact that during the dream, Gordie did not cry during the funeral so this could also mean that his father really did tell him that he'd with Gordie had died instead of Denny. This is portrayed in the movie's great use of dialogue in certain situations such as Gordie and Chamber's heart to heart conversations. Though the dialogue portrayed throughout most of the movie comes off as cheesy and unrealistic in terms of how the youth would speak otherwise, this could have just been dialogue taken from Stephen King's novel. Again, I didn't read the book, and I wasn't born in the 50's. Anyways, I thought the movie was great, and definitely sent an inspiring message to those who aspire to do something great for themselves. These are my basic feelings about the movie and the moments that stuck out to me most. 1,000 words isn't enough for a full review unfortunately.

Absolutely loved this film,its a short but fun packed film with lots of adventure. The relationship that the characters have with each other is very beautiful i could really relate to their feelings. It is a very bittersweet film but also contains humor, i could defiantly watch it again. There were quite a lot i movie mistakes that i noticed but it didn't effect the quality of the film. It is a very memorable film that really makes you reflect on life. I loved the plot and the acting was very real to watch. Its a lovely teenage movie but is also a good film to watch with the family if you get the chance, this is defiantly one of my favorite films and its really worth watching!

Review title: Outstanding Performances, especially from River Phoenix
Review_body: I only discovered this movie in the summer but as soon as I started watching it I knew I would never forget it. As I didn't know any of the cast because the movie was out before my time I looked them up, River Phoenix being of particular interest. As soon as I saw that River had actually passed in 1993 my heart sunk a little bit, his acting in Stand By Me is incredible and definitely some of the best acting I've ever seen. I have took it upon myself to watch all of Rivers films, he was a very talented but underrated actor and my heart hurts for such a tragedy to have happened to him. All of the boys provide an outstanding performance, from the heart breaking scenes of Chris Chambers crying his eyes out to the boys insulting each other and uncontrollably laughing. When I found out River actually couldn't stop crying after they shot his crying scene I truly felt for him. The ending when Ben. E Kings, Stand By Me plays I got shivers as the song just sums up the film. This film is a true masterpiece and I hope that its legacy lives on for a very long time as it is truly amazing and will forever be a favourite of mine.

This movie is definitely a classic. It takes you on a journey with 4 young boys to find a missing body. The thing I love most about this film is the characters. As they go on this journey, you see their strengths and weaknesses. You also see their friendship grow and strengthen.One of my favorite scenes in this movie is the train track scene. Its hilarious and intense and beautiful all at once.This is one of those movies where you notice something new about it every time. It was filmed very brilliantly because the director used the captured setting very well. The small beaten down town was clearly not Hollywood, it felt real and relatable. If you haven't seen this movie, I highly recommend it. One of my all time favorites.

Stand By Me, the 1986 coming-of-age film, directed by Rob Reiner, and based on the Stephen King short story The Body, is one of my so called 'Perfect Films.' A perfect film to me has all of the elements of a good story: comedy, adventure, horror, suspense, and romance. Yes, this movie does not have romance, but in a way it does: in the sense of being in love with your youth during an adventurous summer.The film Stand By Me is a timeless one. It's the kind of film that when you see it for the first time, or the 50th time, it gives you that nostalgic feeling of familiarity, that safe feeling of pre-pubescent adventure and care-free outlook.The actors are great, perfectly cast, and deliver fine performances across the board. Arguably it is an all-star cast: Richard Dreyfuss (narrator), River Phoenix, Jerry O'Connell, Corey Feldman, Will Wheaton, Kiefer Sutherland, and John Cusack to name a few. They all respectively show great range, and are all perfectly cast.The film takes place in Oregon, during Labor Day weekend of 1959. Like I said before, it is based on Stephen King's The Body, which is in his short story collections Different Seasons (which also has Rita Hayworth and The Shawshank Redemption and Apt Pupil so it's awesome). The adult Gordie Lachance (Dreyfuss) narrates the story via flashback while writing a novel. The flashback tells the story about him and his friends embarking on a quest to find the body of a local, missing boy near the town of Castle Rock. Speaking of Castle Rock, the antagonist here is Sutherland's younger Ace Merrill.While the story unfolds, it is revealed that all of the boys are dealing with their own personal issues, all while helping each other in their own way. Gordie (Wheaton) is still grieving and guilt-ridden over the death of his older brother, Teddy (Feldman) is an abused child desperately in denial of his father's malice, Chris (Phoenix) comes from a broken home, and Vern (O'Connell) is shy and timid, while trying to make his way.We learn more and more about each individual as they trek on through the Oregon wilderness in order to find the body, but what they are really searching for are themselves. We start to care more about the characters, and one-by-one we begin to relate to them. The 1950's contemporary rock and roll soundtrack really plays into the story too.The film and story age very well, which can be very tough to do when using a period piece that takes place from another decade. They don't need to rely on special effects and technology, and the dialogue from King's work is carefully chose and respective to that time. The set decorations (see the general store), and costumes, are perfectly chosen.Stand By Me is brilliantly woven using comedy (watch for the pie-eating contest scene), horror (the boys' imaginations in the forest), drama, suspense, and adventure. It's reportedly one of the few film adaptations of his works that Stephen King likes, and I think they got it right too.

Review title: My Favorite Movie of All Time
Review_body: I doubt I can add much of anything which hasn't already been said out of the near-600 reviews at the time of my submission, but I will provide my input, anyway; because this is detailed, my comments will contain spoilers.As is stated, Stand By Me depicts a group of four twelve-year-old boys who embark on a weekend-long journey and learn much about themselves and each other along the way. Gordie is book-smart and gifted in writing, but shy and very insecure. Having lost a few months earlier his biggest supporter, his older brother Denny, he is ignored at home and believes the wrong son's life was taken. He seeks solace around the company of the other three boys, especially his best friend, Chris. While Chris is viewed as "the tough guy" on the surface level, we find that he bears much compassion, as well as a soft- spoken disposition in several instances. As the gang's leader, Chris not only serves as the backbone of the group, but also as a father figure to the other boys, especially Gordie; and, he is the group's peacekeeper.  He comes from an abusive home, but seems to accept that's just who his father is; however, he also believes that he is doomed to the failure attached to his family name. Even more troubled is the maniacal army brat, Teddy. Although his father may have served in the military, it appears that some of his time in combat may have been exaggerated; however, I don't believe it is fully intentional of Teddy to be deceptive, but rather that he is creating for himself an illusion of what he wishes his father was, or perhaps used to be (the fact that Teddy knew the location of the Back Harlow Road because he and his dad used to go fishing there suggests a greater presence from his father when Teddy was younger). Then we have Vern, who is often clueless and fearful of everything, and a comedic element throughout all of the film.  We know nothing about his parents, other than that his mom cleaned out his room.  In any case, the overall lack of parental guidance is a core reason why the friendship among all of the boys is so important.Of course the group dynamics, and especially the increasing bond between Chris and Gordie, is the focal point throughout the story.  Although it is mainly Chris who delegates the gang's course of action (and at times, Gordie as well), decisions are run by all of the gang (Vern usually being the exception).  However, the group must also deal with the bickering and occasional harsh exchanges of words among one another.  There is the consistent squabbling between Teddy and Vern, which essentially makes Chris and Gordie act as "parents" in dealing with them.  And there are several instances in which Chris and Teddy butt heads and nearly come to blows, but they are quickly able to make peace and put their differences aside when it matters. However, most significant  is the friendship between Chris and Gordie.  We see from almost the beginning that the two have mutual respect for one another, with Chris being protective of Gordie. While there exists the looming fear of junior high separating both of them, Chris is willing to sacrifice the friendship in order for Gordie to succeed. However, as the story progresses, and as each tearfully opens up to the other and addresses their own personal demons, we find loyalty between the two friends that ultimately guarantees that whatever happens in life will not come between them.The teamwork and brotherhood mentality of the younger gang is a sharp contrast to the antagonists of the story, Ace Merrill and his gang. However, it is Ace who gives out all orders regardless of what anyone else might want; and he alone is truly heartless, as evidenced in the showdown during the climactic scene in which his gang --- including Chris' older brother Eyeball --- become disturbed by his actions.  But the harsh discourse between the two gangs also reveals the true loyalty between Chris and Gordie: in the beginning Chris defends Gordie to Ace and is thrown to the ground; then eventually, Gordie stands up to Ace (while Vern and Teddy run), putting his own future safety at risk, but ultimately saving Chris' life. In that showdown scene, we also find Gordie to discover an inner strength just moments after having told Chris that he wished his own life had been taken rather than his brother's; and for Chris, I think he realized that he could indeed choose a better path than his family and especially Ace.  This scene, along with the others aforementioned, were undoubtedly the main reasons why Gordie and Chris' friendship thrived throughout their school years while drifting apart from the others; and although life might have gotten in the way after college and they hadn't seen each other for a number of years, the friendship was never lost.And while it's indeed tragic that Chris' life came to an abrupt end, we must remember that he was able to go on to college and live a productive and adult life.  Assuming he was around 38 years old when he died, he still lived much longer than his real-life portray-er, River Phoenix.I have loved Stand By Me ever since I first saw it on HBO/Showtime a year after its release and cannot count the hundreds of times I have watched it throughout the years.  Although I loved the performances of everyone in the cast, like most everyone else I favored that of River Phoenix the most; his work in this film was what made him become my favorite celebrity.  After his passing I was unable to bring myself to watch this story again for a few years, but today I can without reservation state that this is my favorite movie of all time.

Good story about childhood. Parents, freedom, dreams. And friends. Real friends.
This scenario is simple. After watching the film, there remains a slight aftertaste of losing something important. Something that will never return.

I am 16 years old and first saw this at my old best friends house when we were about 14 its her favourite film and also one of mine. I love river and Corey! If you haven't seen this film YOU MUST ! Corey and river are great actors and make this film realistic, they couldn't have chosen any one better to play there roles. My favourite part has to be when they are singing and running down the train track, it reminds me of when i was about 10/11 and how sad i was hahaha as me and my friends used to play on a run down train track near my house, but then they all moved and we have all grown up a little , so it reminds me of some of my memories....i give it 10 Star's ********** !

Review title: In my real life I WAS "Vern" the shorter, heavier of the main 4 boys in movie
Review_body: This story was based loosely on when Stephen King and I were young together ,,,, In real life Stephen was the tallest of the 4 main boys ,,, and I was shorter, heavier Vern who jumped off the bridge ....We were 36 when movie was done ,,, so Corey Feldman played Stephen and Jerry O'Connell played my part ... At the end of the movie, it said that we would meet in the Seventh Grade ,,, and that is the first year we had Elementary School together ..... For six years of schooling we had over 1100 lunches together and every class except Driver's ED and one other ,,,, He was a great friend although I never saw him over-emotional like in the movie ... the stories I could tell ,,, In the movie Richard Dreyfus did a wonderful job narrating the story,,,sounded just like Stephen //// The movie is wonderful ,, with nostalgic tones all over it, especially the music ,,, The description of Jim was correct at the end ,, he was an attorney who passed away about 40 ,,, but I never drove forklift and left Maine to go to College at a wonderful Christian College near Chicago (notice I never said a bad word in Movie?) I write too ,, but Bible projects ,,,I have a nice mansion upstairs and 500 years from now they will still be reading my books...
This film has had a huge impact on my life, and I've enjoyed sharing it with my son.Fantastic, a must watch!

The movie Stand by Me is a story about four close twelve year old friends growing up in rural Oregon who are bitten by the curiosity bug. The main Character, Gordie (Wil Wheaton), and his three friends, Chris (River Pheonix), Teddy (Corey Feldman), and Vern (Jerry O'Connell) set out on an adventure to find the body of Ray Brower. They had heard of his whereabouts by Vern's older brother and they were determined to find him. They incur many setbacks during their journey. They are bullied by the older boys of the town who are also trying to find the body and get the fame, attacked by the junkyard dog Chopper, almost getting run down by a train, and attacked by the swamp leaches. The boys learn many lessons on their journey, but more importantly they learn about life. The actual goal of Rob Reiner, director of the film, was to show that growing up has its ups as well as downs. All four of the main characters have had some trouble in their life. He showed this when Gordie's athletic brother was tragically killed in a car accident. By doing this, Reiner elaborates to the audience that bad things do happen to the best people. Chris and Teddy also have very neglecting fathers at their homes. Even though it is all fun and games on the hunt for the body, they still have a troubled life lingering in the background that they can not get away from. And good old Vern has an older brother who wreaks havoc in his life. He is actually one of the older bullies also on the hunt for the body. Reiner cannot make his point much clearer. One of the things I really loved about this movie is how few rules the young twelve year old boys had. The first evident thing is when the movie opens and they are smoking in their tree house. These boys smoke, shoot handguns in town, and cuss like sailors throughout the movie and know one seems to notice. Wow, the times sure have changed since I was a young child.

Review title: Four young boys set out to find a missing body and in return find out about themselves and each other.
Review_body: The first time i saw Stand By Me on television [ i was thirteen and still am ] it didn't exactly captivate me, but for some reason i felt the need to rent it because i wasn't sure if i saw the whole thing. The second or third time i watched it i got this strange feeling about it and realized i loved it. I feel the same exact feeling when i watch it to this day. I felt a bit guilty not knowing whether i liked the movie itself or just River Phoenix but i came to find that it is a brilliant film and is also very heart warming. The whole plot was unique and i respect both Stephen King and Rob Reiner for displaying a marvelous and beautiful story to the world. I believe that anyone can enjoy a film so truthful and realistic.

How a guy in his forties can remember being twelve this well is a miracle to behold!!  The simpler times, the incredibly close ties of youth, the miraculous acting by such young actors - River Phoenix was better than 99% of the adult actors in that year or any other.  Plus, the drama is tight. Scenes like the train on the bridge, the dog in the junkyard and the leaches in the swamp all kept the thrills coming while this truly human story stayed true to it's recollections of youth.  Even the comedic element was carefully balanced into the mix of movie magic.  With the tubby kid as the brunt of most jokes and scenes like the pie-eating contest with "Lardass" starting the biggest barf festival ever, this movie had every element of great entertainment and true art - because it told the truth about the realities of youth;  how scary and truly barbaric the bullies of youth are, how incredibly horrible adults can be to kids and how damaging it can be to their self-esteem, and then how amazing it is when kids can surprise everyone and do something nobody expects of them, because they've forgotten about the courage that can be exhibited when children  or anyone does the unthinkable because they don't think about or know the consequences that can come from their actions. All and all a great movie.

Review title: This wonderful movie opens the place where your secret heart is buried
Review_body: In ancient Greece people watched the great tragedies in the amphi-theatres, and eyewitnesses tell us that audiences of 20'000 sat crying when the main character on the stage became aware of his fatal guilt and had to face death. They called it catharsis, best translated by 'cleaning the souls'. Well, measured by the tremendous effect on all of us writing reviews on the film, STAND BY ME has the power and qualities of ancient tragedy. This jewel of a film touches and shakes the best sides in us. I have watched it over and over again, and even if I watch it several times a week I still sit and laugh and cry, and it leaves me sad and confused and grateful, feelings that can last for hours and sometimes days.So what is the mystery behind this masterpiece?First of all it teaches us that good filmmaking isn't about the dollars spent on the production, but about the people who make it.And it's about a unique and humble (I hope you understand what I mean) director: Rob Reiner doesn't try to show how good he is, leering at the Oscar-jury:the story is told without any visual effects, the pace is slow and the cinematography is unspectacular, but he succeeds in inspiring his young actors to perform honest feelings and letting the story develop by its own terms. An example is the milkmoney-scene. It is told that Reiner wasn't satisfied with the performance of River Phoenix. They tried again and again. Finally, he told River to remember a situation of his own life where a grownup had let him down. Guess if he succeeded with it! River Phoenix started crying and he couldn't stop crying a long time after the shot was taken. That's why this film is pure gold: it doesn't show professional acting, it shows young boys who open their hearts in front of a camera. They can do it, because they can relate to similar experiences and because the message is important and universal. We all can relate to similar situations. These scenes make me remember events from my own youth that I had inhibited for a long time, because I didn't like to remember them. That's the pain!But it's not only the director and the actors who should earn all the credits. I read the novel after watching the film, and since that time Stephen King is one of the great contemporary writers in my book. I just don't understand why he doesn't write more of THE BODY kind. To me this book is pure poetry (including all those four-letter-words that Maltin e. a. don't like, because they don't understand why they are necessary)! But the most amazing thing is: the script doesn't only catch the quintessence of the novel, it's partly even better! This perfect balance between humor and seriousness! It doesn't manipulate the audience. In the book grownup Gordon sits in his car when he had read about his friend's death. "I drove out of town, parked, and cried for him. Cried for damn near half an hour, I guess." In the film Gordon doesn't cry. He doesn't need to. Everyone in the audience feels like crying, because they understand the tragedy! There are only 13 pages of dialogue and narration, and there really is not one line too much. It's so good, I almost know the whole of it by heart. Take the ending: In the book, the famous writer Gordon Lachance tells about how he met Ace Merrill again, some twenty years after the Ray Brower event: grown fat and the only one alive of his old friends and enemies. How much better is the film's ending! This important line about the friends we had when we were twelve years old is only a line in King's book, commending the good time the boys have at Milo Pressman's junkyard! If there had been an Oscar for impressive film endings, this film had deserved the first!And thank you Jack Nitzsche for the intense score. It's Gordie's theme, when he's not with his friends. In the group Gordie is the smart boy with the sharp, quick, fresh replies. Without the friends, at home or in the store he barely speaks a word. And then we can hear that fragile Jack Nitzsche variation on Stand by me. It's like Gordie crying `where are you, Chris? Come, stand by me'. That's brilliant and exactly what great filmmusic should be: serving the film's dramaturgy.Well, I don't know how many hours it took me to express my love to this film in a language that isn't my own. It seems impossible. It is exactly as Stephen King expressed it himself (end of chapter 29): `Even if I'd known the right thing to say, I probably couldn't have said it. Speech destroys the functions of love, I think - that's a hell of a thing for a writer to say, I guess, but I believe it to be true. If you speak to tell a deer you mean it no harm, it glides away with a single flip of its tail. The word is the harm. Love isn't what these asshole poets like McKuen want you to think it is. Love has teeth; they bite; the wounds never close. No word, no combination of words, can close those lovebites. It's the other way around, that's the joke. If those wounds dry up, the words die with them. Take it from me. I've made my life from the words, and I know that is so.'10 out of 10, no doubt about it!

Review title: This film is so good. A masterpiece.
Review_body: This film is funny, nostalgic and so amazingly true to life that you can't stop thinking about it for days. The acting is superb flawless. Looking back on our childhood is something we all do from time to time and this film relives such things that we have all experienced from time to time. It is really heavy in parts and makes you think about stuff. The pie eating contest is the ultimate. So witty and well done. What more can you say about such a film. Has the best final line of any film I have ever seen."I've never had any friends at any point in my live quite like the one's I had when I was twelve years old, man, does anyone"A perfect way to describe what this film is all about.

Review title: One line can't do this film justice!!
Review_body: I've never met anybody who doesn't like this film. I don't believe there is anyone!! Regardless of those 89 people who voted that it was rubbish. This film is wonderfully cast and definitely does the book(Different seasons, the body, Stephen King) justice which is a change as when literature takes to celluloid it usually manages to get somewhat 'mangled' along the way. However, Rob Reiner captures perfectly the very qualities that made the book so special. This is a film that must be watched by everyone before making a decision. It's too easy to say 'that sounds boring'. as Steven King appropriately states in the book "The most important things are the hardest to say because words diminish them. It's hard to make strangers care about the good things in your life". I'd just like to add at the end of my review, Stand by me beat that timeless classic Top Gun to the number one spot in box office ratings!

Review title: Four boys learn about the adult world
Review_body: An Adventure That Touches the SoulThe film, 'Stand by Me' is based on a novella called 'The Body', by Stephen King and it was released in 1986. The film is based in the 1950s and is about a group of four children, Gordy, Chris, Vern and Teddy, who are aged around 12 years old, who come from a small town in Oregon, called 'Castle Rock'. The title of the film is eye catching and reaches the inner depth of the film, as the four friends have not had the great start in life and they rely on each other for comfort and support.The film follows the children as they set off on a journey to find the body of a boy called Roy Brower who had gone missing. The journey of the boys is along a train track. They have to overcome various perils on their journey such as leeches, trains and knife waving bullies. During their journey they find a lot out about themselves and each other through their continuous conversations. Another group of boys, who could be described as the 'bad lads' are also on the trail of the dead body and it comes to a competition of who will find the body first.I really liked the authentic 1950s setting of the film. This is because of the ways this was implemented. For example, the boys discuss hitch-hiking, which was probably the norm back then, but not now. I also liked the 1950s cars used and the country and western music. The music though is a very integral ingredient in the overall nature of the film. The song 'Stand by Me', by Ben E King is almost spiritual and heart breaking and adds to the authenticity by making the film seem older than it really is. The film also contains music that the children would have liked at that time such as 'Lollipop' by 'The Chordettes'. Throughout the film there are very specific special effects to build up the suspense such as slow motion and stills. The slow motion is very good at helping the viewer to concentrate on hidden detail such as facial expressions and hand and body movements. Another part of the film I liked was the implementation of the train track. This seems to have a symbolic meaning in the film, which I will discuss later. Also, the use of the track and steam trains makes the film seem more like a western than anything else. The film was over-all very good and could be classified as one of my favourites, but I found the beginning part quite slow, although this part does help the viewer to get to know the personalities of the characters involved, so this may be a good aspect. I also found the excessive vulgar language by the actors quite unnecessary and could not understand why it should be used in a film like this. Although other films have vulgar language and it seems today that it is the norm of any film, which has an age rating of over 12. The film contains four main characters. The narrator, Gordy is the most sensible member of the children. He has lost his older brother, who he had a very close relationship with and his parents are much traumatised. In the film Gordy has a dream about his brother's funeral, where his Father turns to him and says.'That should have been you Gordy'. There is no evidence given by Gordy whether this did actually happen. However, the viewer could believe that this did, due to the continual flashbacks that Gordy has of his bad home life. Another character is Chris, who comes from a bad family and is the leader of the children. He is very protective of Gordy and both of them give each other plenty of advice. Vern is the main source of humour in the film and could be described as the geeky character. Not much comes to light about his home background and he has a sense of humour that his character doesn't know he is using. The final main character is Teddy, who can only be described as a crazy character. He is abused by his Father, who is referred to as a loony. However, he is fiercely loyal to him and will not tolerate any comment made against him. There is also evidence in the film that he might even be slightly suicidal. I really liked the way the actors played their parts and also used their own personalities to enhance the overall attitude of the film. The other group of boys who are also looking for the body would not be liked by the audience, especially their leader who carries a knife as if he is pre-meditating a murder. I would like to say that I really enjoyed the film because of how suggestive it was. There was a difference in opinion between four 12 year old boys and the police. What would be a horrible search by the police is an eye opener and adventure for the four children. The film is a 'coming of age' production and the train track could be described as life that the children are leading or opinion, as they learn the terrors of the adult world. Also the four boys and their 'bad lad' followers are like good and evil, which meet at the end in a final showdown. The film could be described as funny, light-hearted, but ultimately deeply harrowing because of the nature of the plot. Star Rating  5

Review title: The Pleasantly Unexpected Story of Four Young Boys Finding the True Meaning of Friendship
Review_body: With its early 60's small-town atmosphere demonstrated through unparalleled friendships, old cars, and a sentimental score, "Stand by Me" is a visual masterpiece that provides the viewer with the warm nostalgia of how simplistic childhood was. Set in Castle Rock, a small town on the north-eastern side of Oregon, four young boys set out a life-changing journey to find a missing body that was rumored to be located near a local riverbank. While on this journey, the group of young teens experiences many valuable events that not only change who they are on the surface but also fundamentally change their outlook on life. Alongside its profound nostalgia, the film carries the audience in and out of a wide range of emotions from euphoria to anguish.Bruce A. Evans' third film, "Stand by Me" flawlessly captures how immature twelve-year-old boys converse with each other, by utilizing an intricate script that shows their transformation through numerous emotional situations. This film was not Evans' first to hit the big screen and prove to be an enormous success, but it was his pioneer film that utilized children in the starring roles. This movie was arguably the first major film to employ the tactic of sending a deep and complex motif to the audience through non-developed, immature actors. Although this motif could have been demonstrated by using more refined actors, Bruce A. Evans took a leap of faith that seemed to pay off in the end. The numerous motifs and messages that this film exemplified could not have hit as close to the heart if it were to utilize adult actors.Although these children were astounding, the actors seemed shallow during some of the more intense scenes. Yes, the script excellently developed the relationship between two of the four boys, but the other two seemed like their origin stories were missing. The primary flaw of the film is that much of the relationships built out were not shared equally among the four protagonists. The backstories that the boys talked about were well written to provide the "team of teens" with a balanced character portfolio but left a weird feeling when the two outsiders were included in the conflicts. This made it extremely difficult to feel fully comfortable with serious scenes that involved the whole gang.While there were some character elements that the script could have better refined, the film perfectly captured the warm feeling that is attached to a small town during the year of 1959. The countless examples that were located in the backdrop of every scene helped immerse the viewer into the period that the movie takes place. Whether it be the numerous Chevy pickup trucks that lined the main street, "Rockin' Robin" that always seemed to be playing over their small transistor radio, or the fact that twelve-year boys were smoking cigarettes in almost every scene, this masterpiece perfectly encompasses a snapshot of what the early 1960s would look like."Stand by Me" flawlessly balances a roller-coaster of emotions through a life-changing journey that exhibits how quickly the innocence of childhood can fade and your outlook on life can be altered. Despite the shallow background of some of the characters and the mediocre performance by the four boys, this movie leaves the viewer with a heartfelt reminiscing feeling that most films strive to accomplish after the film has faded out of the screen.

i would firstly like to apologize for the poor quality of my English, and also to express my frustration and regret for not possessing a rich enough vocabulary to convey my feelings towards this film. But anyway. I first saw stand by me when i was- must have been about 10 years old. At the time, those boys in the film were `big boys` to me and i remember how sweetly river phoenix's flawless profile remained in my innocent childhood memory for days after seeing it, and the very surreal sense of loss and grief i felt when my sister gently told me that he was already not with us anymore. I have been watching this film at least once every year since then for 8 years, and although this is such a cliche the more i see it the more I derive. It's like a film that teases out the knots that form in your heart as you get older, and every time i see it i feel so small again, so unspoiled and vulnerable. No other film has the same effect on me, and i won't bother going into detail about exactly whose amazing acting captivates me and how much of a genius Stephen King is- i don't think all that makes for enjoyable reading when coming from people you don't know. Stand By Me is a beautiful work of art that simply flows- flows right into the forgotten and dehydrated part of our hearts.

Stand By Me is an excellent adaption of Steven King's 'The Body'. I have been using it as an extra text for English for my HSC and have found it so useful as it conveys many themes and ideas and the techniques are extremely well utilised. It is well adaptable to any area of study, for me it has been Journeys, Changes and Story Telling.The story is well directed and written and the focuses upon the changing nature of friendships and the trials and tribulations of growing up and maturing have brought about a deeper meaning for the movie as a text. It is a good representation of the 'coming of age' experienced by many of us. The cast of young actors work brilliantly and their acting is deserves great commendation. The characters are well developed and we can see them as they mature and grow up on this journey of self discovery and how their bonds of friendship change as a result of this. This is examined quite well and we see that friendships change, after all, Teddy and Vern become "just faces in the hallway". We also learn that growing up can be hard and sometimes confusing, and finding yourself in a world where you are the forgotten child, may be the hardest thing. Living up to parental expectations, especially after such events that Gordy has experienced would make anyone feel useless and unwanted and a soft spot for him can be developed. I can say I really developed a soft spot for Chris Chambers, as he is labelled as a bad kid and has grown up facing many adversities. He is the glue and the peace maker in their childhood friendship, that all though they act all mature and hard-assed, they are merely innocent children. Vern on the other hand is the catalyst of the story. He provides the reason for the journey and speeds things along, so as not to become long winded. When obstacles are needed to be overcome, he keeps the boys together and even pressures them into certain decisions (eg train bridge). Teddy is a very lonely boy and has a soft spot for his father, although abused by him , and rumoured to have burnt his ear off. Gordy is in awe of him, as his father tried to kill him and he is deeply moved when the junkyard owner calls him a "loony". Gordy is confused because his own father has never really come near him in his life and he doesn't feel anything of his father, maybe even a feeling aversion.I feel the narration is also a very key component of this film. It introduces the time and place of the story and sets the overall tone. It then reappears throughout stages in the text to show the significance of certain events that happen along the way, for example the deer. At the conclusion of the story, it again reappears to help sum up the story and the feelings of the anonymous writer, how he feels that you never have friends like you did when you are twelve years old. It is also by this that he feels you never have the same carefree and innocence that you also once had as a child.Overall this movie is a great movie and I recommend it to anybody who hasn't seen it. It is definitely worth watching, and when you have to pull it apart for school work, it just makes it that much more appealing because you then understand the underlying features of the movie.
