A heart-warming movie, "Stand by Me" takes place in the 50s and brings 4 best friends through an adventurous hike on the train tracks to find a dead body. Rob Reiner's 1986 film is a story of friendship and growing up. These boys have had some of the toughest lives but their stories are one reason this movie is so entertaining. You'd be surprised to learn what they deal with at such a young age. This film does a wonderful job of portraying young friendships during the 50s.
Centered around the difficulties children and families have gone through in the 50s, it realistically brings depth and meaning to what you have imagined during those times. Each of the boys have experienced tremendous pain in their lives. Either from family physical abuse, substance abuse, neglect, and/or death. All have suffered from poverty in these hard times. For example, Teddy grew up with a crazy father--that suffers from war PTSD--that also almost burnt off Teddy's ear. Another example is Chris, who grew up with a bad family and had a reputation that he would turn out bad too. These boys show most of the struggles civilians dealt with back in the 50s.
This friendship is as real as can be and they would do anything for each other. They make fun of each other, as most boys do, they do rebellious stunts that can get them in big trouble, make pinkie swears, but they also care for each other in a way that you don't see in most young friendships. When they get bullied by the older kids, they stick up for each other. They have deep conversations about what they are going through with each other. For example, Teddy tries to do something crazy by standing in front of the train tracks when a train was coming, but Chris pulled him off and yelled at him to knock some sense into him. Another example is when Gordie stays back with Vern when he has to crawl instead of walk on the train tracks on a high bridge since he is afraid of heights. They all love, support, and take care of each other.
In my opinion, they are only 12 and too young for some of the activities that they do. This is mainly because of the environment they are around that force them to be more mature. In the movie, they are out and about without their parents knowing or caring about where they are. They also smoke cigarettes throughout the movie like it is normal. Chris also had a gun which he shouldn't have had excess too. Them acting this way shows the difference between life back then and how life is now.
The directors chose amazing characters that fit the plot perfectly. The main character, Gordie, narrates the movie from himself as an adult, telling the story of him and his friends at a young age. The character is smarter than the other boys and has better chances of a great future. The only thing is, his brother had just passed away and his mother and father ignore him now, since his brother was the favorite. Chris, who is Gordie's best friend, is the leader of the group and has a very compassionate side. He is empathic towards Gordie and is always hard on himself. Teddy has an emotional side when it comes to his father. Vern is clueless character that is brings humor to the movie. They all make fun of him but not to be mean; it's just them being friends. Each of the characters make you feel empathic towards them. They are what makes the movie so great.
"Stand by me" brings funny and traumatic events wrapped up into a powerful movie. It truly shows the strength of how young friendships impact a person with the last line of the movie said by Gordie as an adult, "I never really had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve. ... Does anyone?" This line woke me up to the fact of how sad growing up really is. A bond of friendship is never the same as when we are young. I definitely recommend this movie to anyone who has a heart and the yearn for adventure and friendship.

By far, it is the best adaptation of a King story I have ever seen. And Reiner did a great job. I have owned this movie since I was twelve or so, and I highly recommend it for teens and adults alike. It reminds us of the bond of true friendship, and the reality of life. Great adventure, and though I've seen it 50 plus times (yeah, I can't believe it either...) I still laugh. an 11

This movie is very faithful to the short story, which is beautiful. Stephen King from IT, to the Green Mile, to The Body, has always been able to produce an incredible work of art. From the books to the movies I always find myself at a loss of words. The movie is 10/10 for me. From the heartfelt realization of adulthood that this movie portrays (from the mind of a 12 year old in the story, obviously written by an adult), you understand themes and elements that portray to your daily life.
My favorite instance of writing in the short story being Chris (at 12 years old) understanding the interweaving elements of being an adult with adult ideas stemming from childhood struggles, realized at the precise point In time that it happens (when he's 12). Chris understands his current status in life, and makes sure that main protagonist Gordie understands that life is really real through the eyes of an adult.
I'm on the verge of turning 25, and the elements brought forth in this movie/in the short story for which it's based off of (The Body by Stephen King), are profoundly poetic and beautiful.
Within each scene you understand the struggles that each character is going through, only made true through your own thoughts creates through the movie/short story. Every point made and thematic element is understandable and heartfelt.
This story is truly incredible and worthy of a 10/10 rating. Very moving. Thank you again Stephen King

Stand By Me is a heartwarming coming of age film set in the 50's about a young group of boys setting out on an adventure to discover the body of a missing teen their age. Along the way they end up discovering who they are.I have to say stand by me is my favorite film to watch over and over again. I recently rediscovered it while i was in target and thought to myself HEYY i remember this movie!!!! I thought the acting was superb and true to heart. River Phoenix performance was tear jerking. Its such a shame he died so suddenly, i found it a bit ironic at the end.This movie made me laugh, smile, cry and everything in between. its a good film that has the charm without making it a "chick flick". people of all ages will enjoy this movie, it brings the kid out of you again and makes you think of all your good memories with your friends.

Review title: The best movie ever! everyone will relate to it in some way!
Review_body: Stand by Me is in my opinion the best movie ever made. Not only to will the older generation enjoy this but so can the younger viewers like myself. Wil Wheaton does a fantastic performance as Gordie, both Corey and Jerry are wonderful to watch together. And who could forget the late River Phoenix, As leader of this small gang he leads his friends to see a dead body yet in the end thats not what the movie turns out to be about. Each boy goes through an emotional journey during the movie and as each scene goes by more and more about each of these misfits is revealed. It's certainly a great coming of age movie that all boys will relate to, however that doesn't mean that the girls out there won't love this one- just as much as me.

As previously stated this is my favorite movie. There are multiple reasons i love this movie but the one that stands out the most is how much I can relate to it. Its honestly such a fun movie to watch with your close friends. Its definitely one of those movies that makes you feel good. HIGHLY RECCOMENDED.

This is my favourite film of all time. The story line helps the viewer envisage the times of when he/she were young, without responsibilities and always looking for adventure. Isn't it weird that everybody seemed to have 4 close friends when they were young and one of these being the most loyal you could wish for. Stand by Me is the epitome of everything that being young represented. The viewer is taken back to when they were young and whilst watching the film they also watch their past through the memories the film forces through, all from the relationship with your best friend to the fact that some friend do just become another face in the hall, even though you grew up and matured together. the whole experience forces you to watch it again and again even though every time it makes you sadder and sadder. its an extremely powerful film with 4 great actors acting superb. just wish there were more like it. 10/10

This is one of those movies that you are able to watch over and again. You will never tire from it. As I was growing up, around the same age as the actors, I was able to relate to much of what they were going through. Now, years later, the parallels have just become that much more profound.

This film is such a great film because it really captures what it is like to be a 12 year old kid.  Simple storyline that blossoms with nostalgia for the viewer that can relate to the main characters.  You can watch this film and remember the feeling that you had when you were with your friends at a young age.  The film says it best when the narrator says something to the effect of " I never had friends like the ones  I had when I was 12"

A brilliant rights of passage movie with an outstanding young cast, truly one of the best film adaptions of a Stephen King story to date. Also has a great soundtrack including Buddy Holly and Ben E. King. The Dialogue in this film is brilliant too. Especially the story of Lardass

Review title: One of the Greatest Films of all time
Review_body: Stand By Me would have to be one of the greatest films of all time.I first saw the film when I was about 8 years old(even though I was meant to be sleeping), and even though I didn't understand most of what they were saying I still found it a great film.I rediscovered the film at the ripe old age of ( I'm not joking)12 going on 13. And soon thereafter elected it to be my favorite film of all time.The acting was of a standard I had never seen before. I mean you could really believe that they were real people, not just characters played by actors. Unbelievably talented ones at that. Stand By Me is the kind of film where you can laugh along with the characters, and cry with them to(and cry I'm sure many of you Stand By Me fans did). The kind of film that, each time you watch, you find something you missed the time before. This film reminds you that life is short, and friendships are much shorter. Most of all this film makes you believe in yourself, even though others may not.

I'm a 14 yr old girl and i feel like a traitor. I loved "Now and then", the girls version of Stand by me, but i thought Stand by me was so much better! We saw this film at school, and when the class ended, we had only gotten through half of the movie! I couldn't wait till the following week to see the rest! I was so desperate that i watched every clip ever made about the film on the web, and i read most of the reviews. The characters were so wonderfully acted. Especially River Phoenix, i found the milk-money scene so touching it made me cry...in class! I recommend this movie to everyone. I love it.

Review title: greatest movie about every boy's childhood
Review_body: this is one of my all time favorites. hits me every time i watch it. and i feel like it describes my youth as i share many of the same stories (except for the whole dead body thing of course). it captures what it was like to be a youth and reminds me of what it was like growing up with that close friend or friends. I watched it when i was about 12 or 13 with my best friend and it definitely described us, our closeness and willingness to stick by each other no matter what. We have since lost touch with each other but i still think back often of the many good times we had together and all of the memories we made. back when you spent all summer long hanging out and having sleeping overs at your friends, before you had to worry about getting a summer job and everything else that comes with growing up. This movie makes you remember your youth and it's purity and the gift of close friends.this quote from the movie just about sums it up: "I never had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve. Jesus, does anyone?"

a great movie for everyone, it harks back memories of your own childhood and what you did with your freinds. Truly an amazing film with a film score to match. one for eveyone and for all ages. The story is moving yet inspirational. The narrative has strands from everyday life in it. The film oozes class with its direction and its moral outlook on life.

Review title: Don't let the rating scare you away!
Review_body: My brother and I saw this movie in our creative writing class (as a character development assignment) and it was so good we bought it. Then we watched it with our 9-year-old sister, and she thought it was boring. Yeah, younger kids might think this movie is boring because there's no violence or "exciting" action in it. But if you're old enough to appreciate it, you'll definitely be sucked in by the plot and the characters. Gordie- the sensitive writer, Chris- the misunderstood peacekeeper and leader, Teddy- the wild, crazy kid who keeps the story interesting, and Vern- the pet who flinches when you punch the air in front of him.This movie is rated R, even though the main characters are 12-year-olds. The reason why is that the F word is used more than twice, actually about 6 times. These kids do swear a lot, but have you ever heard 12-year-old boys talking to each other before?This is now officially my favorite movie. Watch it if your life to be FULFILLED or you'll never forgive yourself!

Review title: Great film based off a great book
Review_body: "Stand By Me" is probably Rob Reiners masterpiece. Based off the great Stephen King short story, "The Body", it is a tale about youth, growing up, bullies, bad relationships with parents and friendship. The plot is about 4 friends who find out about a teenager who was hit by a train a couple miles down the train-track, and set out to find his dead body. Each kid has family issues. Gordie's (Wil Wheaton) close brother who was loved more than him died in a car crash a year previously and his parents couldn't care less about him. Chris (River Phoenix) has two rebel brothers which gives him an instant bad rep and the fact that the town thinks he stole lunch money from school doesn't help it. Teddy (Corey Feldman) has a mental father who burnt both of his ears off on a stove and Teddy is almost as crazy as him. And Vern (Jerry O'Connell) is the chubby runt-of-the-pack who also has a rebel for a brother. The four characters have great chemistry and give entertaining and funny conversations. The film perfectly captures the environment, expressions and style of the 50's. There are several intense, surprising, funny and sad moments in this great adaptation. It is one of my favorite films.

Review title: best movie ever, fickle as i am, can't beat this one, period.
Review_body: If you have not yet seen this movie you must.  I think anyone who goes through they're life, especially childhood, without seeing this movie is seriously missing out ona  great plot, great quotes, and great acting. The acting is so spectacular that i am inspired to try to become an actress myself.  After watching this movie, River Phoenix's death was so much closer to the bone, he could've been larger than life and to me, and i bet lots of others, he already was in his short time on the earth.  Wil Wheaton was the most adorable thing in the world in this movie and having seen picture of him today, he hasn't lost that cuteness he had in '86.  Corey Feldman, awesome, just great, i wish he would appear in more stuff today, "The Lost Boys" and "Stand By Me" make you love him soo much, he just attaches to you. The characters are so real even if you're a girl, an adult, or a boy with a childhood exactly like this.  The characters are so real, so undescribably cool and soooooo well portrayed.  The actors are even more lovable because they are close to their characters, Rob Reiner (director of Stand By Me) says you must cast them that way because they have not "developed the craft [of acting]."  So they really are like that!! It makes me so happy to know those guys are so real, very comforting in this new world of mondo-commercialization.

Review title: "You never have friends as good as the ones you had when you were twelve"
Review_body: Stand By Me is the story of one-of-a-kind friendships. The movie starts out with a man writing a book recalling that "you never have friends as good as the ones you had when you were twelve". The author is who the movie revolves around, Gordie Lachance. Gordie (Wil Wheaton), Chris (River Phoenix), Teddy (Corey Feldman), and Vern (Jerry O'Connell) are four friends who embark on a journey of their life at the age of twelve. They set out to find the body of a dead kid, whom Vern overhears his brother stating the boy's location, but the foursome end up facing many obstacles along the way including a bully, Ace, played by Keifer Sutherland. While the boys are going to a grim destination, the bond and adventure that they endure is one that will last them a lifetime. A theme of this film would be to enjoy your childhood because growing up sucks and happens way faster than you realize. Gordie realizes this after the death of his older brother at which point he becomes invisible to his parents. All four of the boys came back from their journey with a new sense of maturity. I think seeing the dead boy along with the run-in with Ace's gang contributed to that along with other iconic scenes such as sleeping in the woods, Chopper, and swimming with the leeches. Another good movie that has the same theme as Stand By Me would be The Goonies. Both movies have a group of kids set out on an adventure that end up growing a little on the way. The scene in which Gordie and Chris are talking about Gordie taking advanced classes when they go back to school uses lighting to contribute to the theme. The lighting is soft on Gordie which makes him seem very childlike and hard on Chris with makes him seem more mature. This was kind of ironic as Chris was the one that was supposed to be the trouble maker and who I think would be considered childish whereas Gordie is more mature most of the movie. For example, Gordie doesn't horse around as much as the other three boys. I think the radio music also contributed to the theme since it was happy 50's music used as a motif to portray happiness, which goes along with most childhood memories especially those with your friends. In conclusion, enjoy your childhood while you still have it. As this movie teaches the viewer, it goes by way too fast. We always seem to take time for granted and issues that occurred while we were young seemed such a big deal then but now we know that they were trivial compared to issues that we have to face as adults.

I must have seen this movie ten times and each time it gets better. The tale about the lives and adventures of four boys who live through trials and tribulation. I cried with them, laughed with them and felt their fears as my own. That is what this movie becomes...a true experience. Yes I saw it again and I too remembered that not too long ago, I too was like them, a boy with friends who would go to the end of the world, a boy in search of himself. River Phoenix delivers a performance that we have not seen from an actor his age. Truly splendid, leaving one to wonder what he might have achieved only he was still alive. A very poignant ending, where the actor looks back at his life down nostalgia lane and delivers a worldly truth...yes the best friends are those that we had when we were still young, free and looking forward to all the challenges the world may hold...for we were invincible then!!Its a movie you should watch and once you have you should try and relive that age once again. Its a movie which brings your inner child back. Go swimming through swamps, get bitten by leeches, run on rail tracks, taunt the dogs which chase you and most of all enjoy and relish the true friendships that you have and reconnect the ones you had forgotten about.

whether you went in search of a dead body in the 1960s or played neighborhood flashlight tag in the 1980s, this film brings out a sense of nostalgia for all.each one of us can connect in some level to one of the four brilliantly defined characters, as well as finding a best friend in another.  the story line (although incredible and perhaps one of stephen king's best) is really irrellevant.  rather than getting caught up in the story, one tends to find themselves caught up in the emotions, the rite of passage into manhood, and the slow decaying of times so sweet.stephen king's words are not easily put into a movie, and few ever do the books justice.  however, i believe this to the best rendition yet (yes, even beating out shawshank redemption).rarely have i seen a movie that has moved me as much as this one.  jesus, has anyone?

This movie opens so many different emotions in peoples hearts. It works on so man different levels. Everyone with a soul can relate to this movie enjoying a long summer with your friends and facing something scary and coming together when the going gets tuff. This is a rare and emotional film about the experiences of growing up and what kids face. Stand by me has to be the best coming of age film every maybe even the best all round film. The cast did a great job in creating a atmosphere that makes us think back to our childhood. i am only 16 and even now i am starting to loose the inocence of youth and growing up. My friends and i were actually like this round about when i was 12. we looked out for each other and then as time went on we started to go our separate ways. I never had any other friends later on in life like the ones i did when i was 12 Jesus does anyone?

Review title: The greatest movie I have ever seen. If you haven't seen it... buy it now.
Review_body: Stand By Me is the most excellent movie I have ever seen, and it definitely deserves a 10/10 without question. When I first saw it, I was amazed at how wonderful and unique this film was. It is absolutely the greatest Stephen King adaptation, and I think it is awesome how Stephen King liked some of the things better in the movie than what he wrote in the book. like when Gordie pointed the gun at Ace instead of Chris. I have never really cried during a movie until I saw this one. It is absolutely beautiful, and I love every second of it. All of the young actors put on memorable performances, especially the late River Phoenix. The adaptation was done brilliantly. If you have not seen this movie, I strongly suggest you do. It is pure genius.

Review title: Truly a masterpiece! i love it!
Review_body: I saw this movie when i was younger and i still absolutley love it. the story itself is just brillant. the actors fit with charaters great! whil wheaton did a fabulos job playing the dramatic kid. river phoniex fit the bad boy with a soft heart image. corey feldman did an awesome job as the "big mouth" type of kid. and jerry o'connell did a treffic as the fat , not to smart but still funny kind of character! The movie let you see that even a boy or man can still cry. It had a great message. Simply the 4 boys ,who realy dont have much family, turn to the only people who can understand and help them in a time of need, their best friends. and its so sweet. This movie is and will always remain my favorite of ALL TIME! If you didnt enjoy this movie the first time watch it again and it will be your favorite too! God Bless.

Review title: Not a synopsis, but a description.
Review_body: This is a beautiful, moving film.  Wil Wheaton delivers an innocent and emotional performance, while River Phoenix acts as the tough kid, protecting Wil, suberbly.  The story is a sad yet uplifting one, and a melancholy rendition of Ben E King's song Stand By Me, washes over the film. All in all I would thoroughly recommend this movie to those who enjoy tales of friendship, suspense and possibly a good cry.  Watch out for Kiefer Sutherland, too, as 'Ace' the vicious gang leader of a group of thugs.

Although I watched it only few months ago, I liked it, I really do. Very good story, talking about 4 truly friends and their adventures. I was very sorry when I found out that River (Chris) died, cause, even he was a drug addict, no young man deserves to die. At least if there was no way for him to find a way out of that hell, his friends should helped him to fight with it, with everything what they could do, and never to give up. Rest in peace my friend.

Review title: One of the greatest movies I think I will ever see,
Review_body: I love this film. The summer before 7th grade when I was 12 (I'm 13 now) my mom recorded this movie for me while I was at my grandparents house over the summer. I came home and she's like "watch this, it's one of my favorite movies" (she grew up in the 80'). I watched it and I remember trying to figure out the meaning. I watched it a few more times and realized I fell in love with it!I understood all the characters feelings, about what its like growing up. I love all the characters and love all the things they go through. It just it makes you feel like your there and gives you this wonderful feeling. I hated it when Ace and his stupid gang would pick on them, and I laughed at all the funny scenes. I loved Teddy's laugh, Vern's scared face, Chris's emotion and Gordie's intelligence. Well, I downloaded it onto my iPod and bought the DVD, so I made sure my friends saw it. Of course they all liked it. Me and my friend Jodi were always "skinin it" and me and my younger friend Meghan still dance to "Lollipop". And for some crazy reason I feel the urge to dodge train near where my dad lives. I did read the story to get more background on the characters and what happened after they went home, all I can say is Stephen King is the "King" :) Very good in how he describes adolesnce.I can relate to how Gordie said he never had friends like the ones he did when he was 12. I know that sounds funny since I'm only 13, but I've lost a few friends. My best best friend Jodi moved to the city, and I miss her, we still talk but I doubt if we can ever meet up again. We had some great times together, we did some stupid stuff that got us in trouble but we have memories. My friend Karina is moving next week to the "city", so thats another friend missing from the lunch table.Friends really do come in and out of your life just like busboys at a restaurant... <3

Review title: Beautiful movie which made me think...
Review_body: I first watched this movie when I was about 13 - and I never forgot it. I never saw it again until about 5 months ago - I'm nearly 17 now.I love this movie because as well as being well directed, well scripted and excellently cast, it made me think back to when I was 12 and the friends I had then. It made me realize that I didn't have friends like Gordie did."Friends come in and out of your life like busboys at a restaurant"Can't get any truer than that.'Stand by me' is a timeless coming-of-age movie that will remain in the memory of all who see it.10 out of 10

If you feel lonely and depressed, this is the film to watch. This great film of a unique friendship reminds you what it was like to be a kid hanging out with your friends, going on adventures etc.I have probably watched this film over 20 times, and it is still as good as it was the first time I watched it, the "magic" is still there.....Great performances, great actors and a great atmosphere (which seem to fill you with some kind of happiness). River Phoenix is terrific. The conversation pieces are brilliant, and several phrases will sit in my head forever.

Review title: The Best Film, The Very Best.
Review_body: It's just the best film. The very best.I watched it first when I was 11, in 1989 or 1990, and I thought it was pretty good. I then became 12, and experienced the most profoundly wonderful time of my life, with my 12 year old friends.I saw Stand By Me again when I was 13 or 14, and it all made sense to me. Ever since, the film has brought out every possible emotion in me, many times over.When River Phoenix died, I couldn't face watching it for a couple of years. The scene at the end where Chris/River 'disappears' - the thought of it killed me. I returned to it after that, but haven't watched it now for at least 3 years, probably more.I know virtually every word, but each time I watch it, something new occurs to me. Whoever put the soundtrack together deserves immense credit, it is beyond poignant, beyond beautiful, beyond words.I often wonder if girls and women are able to appreciate this movie in the same way that boys and men are. I'd be interested in feedback. I have supposed that my intense emotional connection to the characters in this film come from having once been a boy.I have it on DVD and VHS, but so profound is the effect this film has upon me, I am waiting for the right moment. It is always with me though, and for that I dearly thank the writer (and yes, I've read 'The Body' many times over, but this is a very rare case of film being better than book), the director and the actors, and everyone else involved in making 'Stand By Me' the incredible experience it has been for me, over the course of the last 19 years.

Review title: "stand by me" shows that children are more than capable of understanding, feeling and participating in previously described "adult concepts".
Review_body: Modern "coming of age" Dramas seem to display notions of people under 15 years of age being innocents, free from corruption and unaware of tensions between associates of different sexes. Then along comes a catalyst in the shape of going to high school, making a new friend etc. and  all of a sudden a child becomes an adolescent, free from illusions and aware of adult issues. Usually the "coming of age" drama is focused around these issues; of first noticing the opposite sex, of the discovery of a "generation gap" between the subject/s and their parents/guardians, of the discovery of swearing and drinking and occasionally drugs. The thing I liked about this movie is that it highlights the fact that awareness of these issues does not come exclusively with puberty. The characters in this movie smoke, swear, tell dirty jokes, discuss sex, and hate their parents all before hitting their "Teens". It shows that it is naive to assume that it takes 15 years for a child to realise that there is a "generation gap" existing in their household. It also displays an underlying concept that many children are capable of acheiving personal skills that many adults are incapable of; that is the ability to make decisions and stick to them, the ability to lead a group, the ability to take care of themselves, and the ability to problem solve within a group. This concept, that many children depend on their parents for economic support more than emotional support is an edgy one and one that forces veiwers to redefine their mental image of the "child".

It is about four boys , who have heard about a dead boy. All four have different private problems is evident in the film again. Chris has such a big brother, Eyeball, who is leader of a gang of older and known as the city's Habit. Chris has also had a negative image so that he, for example, will always be charged in school when something is lost or destroyed. Gordie is the intelligent. His older brother has recently died. His brother was a popular and talented guy and Gordie feel as if his parents, especially his dad, think it should have been Gordie who died instead. They have heard about a dead guy in their age in the wood. The police have not found him yet, the four friends go out and look for him. I like that all four have problems home but when they are together they live like a little " dream world ". The movie is profound and to see their friendship make me happy !

Review title: Mediocre. I really don't understand all the praise.
Review_body: I just finished watching this movie yesterday. It starts of well enough, in a typical Stephen King fashion. Small town, low population, a group of kids with issues going on an adventure. The acting is solid, in my opinion. The child actors do a fairly good job, with the late River Phoenix and Corey Feldman standing out.My main gripe with this film is that the whole thing feels like one massive prologue, full of buildup, only to utterly disappoint at the end. It's missing the main body and the conclusion. We get introduced to the characters, with each of them being different and relatable in a unique way. We learn about the problems they have to deal with... and that's pretty much the movie. Nothing gets resolved before the credits roll. Just when things are finally starting to get interesting, the movie simply ends. We are given a sentence or two of exposition about what happens to each of the characters we got attached to, and that's it. River Phoenix and Corey Feldman's characters got such an unfair treatment due to this, that you'll stare at the screen in disbelief and just ask yourself "Huh? That's it!? That's the end!? WTF?". Several plot points just never get answered or elaborated upon, at all. It's just over. Fin. The end. That's all, folks!I don't remember the last time a movie disappointed me. as much as this one has. 5/10.

I recently found "Stand By Me" in a closing Blockbuster and in about a week. Since, I have seen it 7 times, 8 if you count the time I watched the Directors Commentary. Everything is great, the acting, the setting, the train scene, with Vern and Gordie, shoot. Like the way the train looked; and the music throughout the entire movie. Corey Feldmen, River Phoenix, and Keifer Sutherland were all spectacular. My favorite scene is where Teddy goes crazy at the junkyard. When I looked at "Walking the Tracks: The Summer of Stand By Me," Rob Reiner says that Corey Feldmen truly had a lot of anger. I see that every time I watch (witch would be many,many times). Truly an unforgettable movie.

This movie brings forth all of the feelings of being a pre-teen and spending a summer of adventure with your friends. The bond between them is expertly portrayed and never overdone which i found rare. The acting of the four boys is superb and natural for the most part, Reiner did a wonderful job directing them. Speaking as a huge fan this is Phoenix at his pure best. Truly haunting. If you enjoy reminiscing then this is a great movie for you! The spectrum of emotions portrayed and invoked in this movie makes this one of the best to have come out of the eighties... Strike that, THE best. Add to all of this the fantastic music and the stunning scenery this is a must see.

Review title: One of the best movies I have ever seen.
Review_body: I have seen a lot of films in my time (I am a fourteen year old female) but never before have I seen a movie so uplifting and memorable as this film is. It is a dynamic coming-of-age film about 4 young boys who set out to find the body of 12 year old, Ray Brower. The casting was brilliant and the plot was magnificent. Rob Reiner directed this movie beautifully and I'm sure Stephen King was impressed as this was an adaptation of his novella 'The Body'. I've watched this movie over and over again and I think I have grown to love it even more. **** 1/2 out of 5

Review title: Epic beyond belief for what it is.
Review_body: "Stand By Me" truly is epic beyond belief for what it is. This is due to various reasons. 1). Its cast is mainly children. Quite often films with casts children dominated lack quality acting as the youngsters simply have just not been in the business long enough to be able to deliver impressive performances. However "Stand By Me"'s young cast all are believable and show great chemistry. River Phoenix in particular is amazing as the brave , yet troubled "Chris". 2). The film is very very short. Quite often the best films are around 2 hours in length. Often this duration is necessary for a film to drum up enough depth for it to stay with the viewer long after the credits. "Stand By Me" has no trouble going into decent amounts of depth and staying with the viewer in only 85 minutes. Its nice to watch a film which doesn't drag on. There is too many of that these days. 3).The focus of this film is on children so you would think it would probably only appeal to a childish audience.Yet it doesn't. It deals with some heavier material than initially expected but this is welcomed by more mature viewers. Plus most of us value our childhoods so its childhood friendship content is refreshing to view as it encourages us to reminisce on our good times of our younger days. In saying that it is epic for what it is I guess it was always going to be in some ways as its written by arguably the most successful writer of the 20th century Stephen King. Richard Dreyfus (Jaws) plays a satisfying side role as the older "Gordie" who narrates the story. "Stand By Me" is an excellent film. i recommend it to anyone who values childhood, friendship or just wants to witness a fine and ultimately moving piece of cinema. "Suck my fat one you cheap dimestore hood" haha "Sincerly"

Review title: Stand by Me has stood the test of time
Review_body: As the summer of 1959 was coming to a close, Gordie, played by Wil Wheaton, and his three buddies, come to a juncture in their young lives – that of crossing over the threshold of childhood naiveté into that of adolescents and coming of age. Stand by Me is a story of lost innocence and growing up.The opening scene is effectively narrated by Richard Dreyfuss. The narration is a prelude to the crux of the movie – a flashback to the summer of '59; a simpler times when kids were kids and void of accountability. Use of flashbacks in this movie is a poignant approach that links the beginning to the end.The friends, bound by tumultuous pasts, set out on a two day expedition to find the body of Ray Brower, a kid whose life was cut short by a passing train. The town thugs also want to recover the body of Ray Brower. Ironically, the thugs and younger group of boys are no strangers to each other; in fact, the two sets of brothers harbor hostility toward one another.Throughout the two day journey, Gordie along with Chris Chamber played by River Phoenix, Jerry O'Connell as Vern, and Corey Feldman as Teddy Duchamp, trudge between boyhood and young men. One minute the boys are dragging on cigarettes and the next minute they are pondering over the notion if the Disney character Goofy is a dog. The foursome share their inner most thoughts to their childish antics. Vern announces that cherry Pez would be his choice of "food" if he were only allowed to choose one food to survive on. As the story unfolds, it is the fateful meeting of the two gangs at the side of the tracks that puts friendship, brotherhood, and maturity to the test.The thematic similarity in Stand by Me and that of the 1995 movie Now and Then resonates the familiar subject of coming of age. Within one short summer the lives of these kids changed forever, resulting in personal growth, and the realization that the events of the summer would change their lives forever.The movie Stand by Me is a convincing representation of transitioning from a child to a young adult. Stand by Me has stood the test of time. Viewers can identify with the film and reminisce about their own loss of innocence and the changes in life that are inevitable.

The film "Stand By Me" is hands down one of my favorite movies of not only my childhood, but even still today. When I look back on my own youth around the years of 12-14, I can remember so clearly the moments portrayed in the film. Whether it be talking smack about our parents, running around all night saying we were each staying at different houses, or walking along the train tracks during the scorching summer days chucking rocks at the freights that passed by. I recall being skeptical at first about watching this so called "classic," simply because of the fact that i was an adolescent girl and not some "young dirty boy" taking hikes to see dead bodies and smoking cigarettes along the way. But from the minute the movie started with all the boys' playing cards in the famous tree house to the moment where Chris Chambers fades away at his and Gordie's final goodbye, I could not help but get a thousand of overwhelming emotions passing through me. I laughed, I cried, I felt angry, and at times even surprised by some of the language that these thirteen year old boys were using. But that is the magic of it all. How often does a movie about pre-teen kids come along where there is no sugar coating, just a plain and real depiction of how all of us acted when we were that age. The average movie always leaves me laughing or feeling entertained for the night, but very so often a dime piece will come along that leaves you in awe feeling nostalgic for days about your own childhood. And then there are the actors - how could I possibly forget about them? River Phoenix with his heart-gripping scene about the milk money, Whil Wheaton so believably portraying a quiet and vulnerable boy who had lost his brother, Corey Feldman evoking so much anger and hurt through the words he says and the emotion in his eyes, and then Jerry O'Connell-just being plain old, clumsy Vern. Rob Reiner also did a fantastic job to have the ability to take a Stephen King novel and turn it into a heartwarming tale that still held the "spooky" element to it all. Filled with an outstanding cast and beautiful theme song, it is no wonder this is a movie I cannot seem to go a year without watching. It is definitely a must see for anyone who feels they want to relive their past every now and again. Like the famous quote says, "I never had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve. Jesus, does anyone?"

Review title: An excellent coming-of-age movie that will warm your heart
Review_body: Stand By Me is a classic film, it is about four boys; Chris Chambers, Gordie Lachance, Teddy Duchamp and Vern Tessio.It's set in the summer of 1959 in a small town in Oregon called Castle Rock. The story starts as a middle-aged man (we soon learn that this is the main character; Gordie looking back at an experience when he was young) tells us: "I was 12 going on 13 the first time I saw a dead human being". This is what the film is about, the four pre-teen boys embark on a journey to find a kid who has been killed by a train as they hope that their discovery will lead to their fame. The characters must travel through fields, forests and even over train tracks to get to their goal. It's not as easy as it seems and in one memorable scene Gordie and Vern almost meet their demise as they scramble across a bridge just as a freight train is passing.Unfortunately, the town's bullies are also out to get to the body for the same reason as the four boys. The bullies and our four boys meet at the end and in a very tense scene (you will have to watch the movie yourself to find out what happens, I'm not telling). But this is not the whole story; in truth it is much more than that. Stand By Me is about friendship and how a single event can change your life forever.Throughout the film we learn more and more about the individual characters, for example: we learn that Gordie is ignored by his parents at home after his older brother had died, Chris and Teddy's Dad's are abusive or just plain deranged and Vern is the awkward kid whom everyone picks on. Though there is a lot of sadness and angst in this film, there are also elements of comedy. The characters are very lovable; you will often understand how they feel regardless if you have been in a situation like the boys.The acting in this movie is absolutely superb, for many of the cast, this was their first film and it does not show. They all look like very experienced actors. They make it ever so much easier to fall in love with every single character.Stand By Me is a film adapted from one of Steven King's novellas; 'The Body'. King has based a lot of the character's adventures on his own childhood in the 1950s. The movie has stayed quite loyal to the film with only minor differences. So if you liked the book then you will definitely like the film.

Just a note - I wrote this for a school project. I would never have the patience to write something this long otherwise.Stand By Me ***** out of 5 DVD edition Viewed March 4, 2005 Based on Stephen King's bestseller The Body Directed by Ron Reiner Dead Bodies, Vomit, Bloody Leeches, Swearing, Knives and Cigarettes: Why This is the movie for your family By Rachael C., FILMAttention parents! What do you want most for your children? Do you want them to become young, successful and aspiring people? Is it your only wish that Joey and Larissa go out into the wide, wide world and inspire other young people as you inspire them? If so, the 89 minutes of film, which stars the young, successful and aspiring River Phoenix, Will Wheaton, Corey Feldman and Jerry O'Connell, is for them.But it's full of dead bodies, barfing, bloody leeches, swearing, knives, and cigarettes!, you say. This is not entirely true. The film, released in 1989 by Columbia Pictures, is not merely about a group of friends who travel along a rail track to find a dead body they have heard about. Themes of heroism, self-confidence and friendship are packed together in hilariously heart warming scenes that flow cleanly form frame to frame. Stand by Me is good for both you and your kids to see because of its realistic plot, the talent of the actors and the youthfulness of the movie.The adventure is seen from the point of view of Gordie Lachance (Will Wheaton) who throughout the trip is tortured by the memory of his older brother, who had just died recently. Chris Chambers (River Phoenix), Vern Tessio (Jerry O'Connell) and Teddy Duchamp (Corey Feldman) all struggle with problems of their own.This movie is what is known as a "coming of age film" featuring characters around 11 to 15 years of age who discover something new about themselves and who they can become through the progress of the story. You may find yourself relating to one of the characters during this movie because the script is incredibly realistic. This reality that you are forced to watch is what will make you both laugh and cry. The way the characters react to each other and the obstacles they face are ways you will remember yourself or your friends reacting. These could just be the facial expressions or words they use, but it conjures up memories of your own childhood. The impeccable performance of the actors in Stand by Me brings in another aspect of realness. The characters are believable, especially in their speech. Although the kids use what is considered to us "foul language", it is how kids of that setting (1950's, fictional town of Castle Rock, Oregon) spoke. The emotions of the audience are constantly changing as each character struggles with his own problems. The main theme of this movie is youthfulness and the friendships we possess at the time. It relishes in both the beauty and the pain of being a kid, as the four friends sing songs at the tops of their lungs, swim in mud, and hold spitting contests, but also experience death, the sheer terror of getting run over by a train and the loss of things special to them(Gordie's hat that his brother gave him). This movie is one your kids will learn something from. And maybe you will learn something from it too. As Teddy Duchamp says, "This is my age. I'm in the prime of my youth and I'll only be young once." Stand by Me will help you relive your youth.

Review title: One of the greatest, severely underrated, moving, funny, nostalgic and so, so true movie's of a lifetime
Review_body: To give this film as high praise at it deserves is near impossible. There is nothing that, given the power, a true movie fan would not change. Stand By Me has bag's full of entertainment, comedy elements and thought provoking scenes with plenty to spare.To brand this a "kids" movie would be so wrong. Simply having children as the lead actors does not take anything away from the movie, it actually makes it the greatest coming of age movie ever, and one of the greatest EVER movies. AND WHAT ACTORS THEY ARE!This story, like so many King novel's, use's character substance to carry it instead of seen-them-a-mile-off constant "twists", trying to hard to be clever plots or poor action. Only actor's of the highest calibre could pull this off (and that includes adults). The actors perfect their parts so much that you feel you personally know each one of them, that you are friends with these people, that you have been on this journey with these people and that is why it saddens come the end of the film. Never before has an audience laughed and cried with movie characters.A portion of this acting praise must go to director Rob Reiner. Only perfect directing could show the boy's talents in their true glorious light, and thank god he did not patronise and treat them as children with how it was shot. Many times the boy's were contained in a group and while this meant them all being on top of their game throughout it brought the film to life and really gave a sense of a close group of friends.The main character here is Gordie LaChance, a boy practically dis-owned by his parents as their favourite, perfect child, Gordie's older brother, has died. This leaves Gordie with no identity and no life purpose, something he will pick up from his journey, as will the others...scaredy-cat Vern, flamboyant army fanatic Teddy and tough-guy with a hard surface Chris.Though maybe not intended i did not see Gordie as the hero in this pic. It was the tragic story of Chris (River Phoenix), who had been severely mis-judged and given the reputation of a "bad kid". This is due to his family reputation, one that Chris cannot shake off. Always the strongest with the most life set-backs Chris is the light of the movie, and River Phoenix the star.One excellent scene in particular, the real gem in this crown, is where Chris (River Phoenix) tells Geordie (Wil Wheaton) about his milk-money experience. It was the strongest point of the film, by far the most emotional and River Phoenix acted well beyond his years, more believable than most adult actors.I cannot rave about the performance's enough. To carry a film that, while already stunningly shot with an excellent 50's soundtrack, needed so much substance to work each actor had to be perfect...and they were. Ace (Kiefer Sutherland) was so realistic, a character representing the boy's problems, Vern (Jerry O'Connell) is that kid we all no from our childhood, Teddy (Corey Feldman) was such an elaborate, original yet realistic character, Gordie (Wil Wheaton) witnessed all of this and listened to his friends problems while suppressing his own, while River Phoenix, as Chris, is all of the above and more. It is Chris who make's you laugh, make's you cry, makes you sympathise with while envy at the same time. He has the most problems in the group yet still put's his friends (particulary Gordie) first, keeps the piece, and keeps the group, and the movie, together.This is beautifully crafted, intensely directed, has an amazing soundtrack, gives a story that has it all and acting performances that make you wonder...where were the Academy? I do not think I build up his performance enough by claiming that River Phoenix deserved an Oscar nomination AND win for his portrayal of Chris. I have not seen that many better performances by an actor, not a child actor, but by actor's in general....EVER! (Only Jack Nicholson in "One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest" & Marlon Brando in "The Godfather" can boast better performances)This film deserves the praise it gets x100. Everything you could want from a movie is here, in Stand By Me, one of the greatest movie's of all time.....Superb 11/10!

Review title: #205?! It should be in the top 10!!!
Review_body: What's not to love about this movie? It is a truly touching film that shows what the friendships of twelve year old boys in the 50s. I cannot express the impact the movie will have on you personally ( ranges for everyone); but it more than likely will change the way you look at life.

This movie, adapted from a book by Stephen King, is not like most of the horror films you may come to expect from this author. While yes, there is a sense or morbidity, this movie is really more about that moment in your adolescence when everything is changing, yet everything is just right. Stand By Me is about four boys who take a trip to see a dead body, and on the way find themselves growing up. There is just the right mix of boyhood (the fart jokes, the rhyming insults, the play-wrestling) and adulthood. The boys enjoy their time, yet are always looking ahead at school next year and whether their friendships will last. River Pheonix delivers an amazing performance as the kid that no one has faith in, and is one of the best child actors I have ever seen. When I heard that he was dead, I was disappointed; he would've been an even more amazing actor later on. Keifer Sutherland also did well as 'Ace', the bully chasing the four boys. He was sufficiently frightening enough to keep us on our toes throughout the movie. This movie is sweet, with a large dose of nostalgia. You want to remember when you were 12, what it was like. You want the boys to succeed in their future, which seems so uncertain. All in all, the line that really sums it up is the last line of the movie: "I never had friends quite like the ones I had when I was 12 years old. But h***, does anybody?"

So when I want to remember the friendships and friends of that time,I watch this movie.This story describes the adventure of boys living in a small town,Castle lock,of Oregon in the 1950s. The main characters are four boys. They each have a traumatic experience. Gordie has an introverted personality and is quite serious too. He has a talent for writing stories. He lost an elder brother in an accident. He is treated coldly by his parents and has an inferiority complex. Chris is a close friend of Gordie. He has a strong sense of justice and is smart. However, his home environment despairs of him badly in the future. Teddy wears big glasses. He longs to join the armed unit in the army,influenced by his father. He respects his father but is abused by his father. Vern is fat and cowardly. They have different personalities and characters but they were good friends.One day,they hear the rumor that a missing boy was dead at the track side at the edge of a town. They go for an adventure in search of the body. The main character finally said. "I never had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve. Jesus, does anyone." I sympathized with those words. And it left an impression on me.Please watch this movie if you want to remember irreplaceable days of the youth.

Stand by me is a timeless classic that will never age. Even though the story is very simple: 'Four 12 year-oldish friends go on a 2 day journey searching for a dead body of a boy they know' it is much more than that.First of all, the actors are perfectly cast and one of the reasons this movie works so well is the brilliant acting and amazing chemistry between the four leads: River Phoenix, Wil Wheaton, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O'Connell. They do such a genuine and believable job here at such a young age and their charisma and characters immediately suck you in and give you a nostalgic feeling that stays with you long after the credits have rolled.The supporting cast is also terrific. The cobras are hysterical with some of their one-liners, Kiefer Sutherland is amazingly believable as the stereotypical bully, and even John Cusack's small, yet memorable scenes add to this wonderful film.Stand By Me is a funny and nostalgic movie, with some of the best one-liners and memorable scenes that will leave an impression on the viewer. I couldn't help but want to call up my childhood friends and discuss one of the best movies I've seen in years.10/10

Review title: Stand By Me a 1986 film. Based on The Body by: Stephen King directed by: Rob Riener
Review_body: Stand By Me is a story of four best friends in the 1980s went on an adventurous trip to find a dead body. It turns out that they begin to come closer and learn more about each other. They are finding out who they are and who they will become.All four kids have parents who could careless about them. One of the main characters, Gordy, had an older brother Denny who died in an accident. Gordy's parents never pay any attention to him and when they do, they nag him about how he should be more like Denny. Gordy's best friend Chris has an alcoholic dad who could careless if he were dead. Chris if like a father from time to time with Gordy. He wants the best for him and he is always there for him.I learned a few lessons while watching this movie. No matter who it is, who ever doesn't believe in you, you don't give up. You need to be yourself with no worries. Don't let anyone expect you to be anyone else but yourself. Gordy's father expects him to be just like Denny. Denny was the only one who really believed kin him. Chris encourages him to not give up. It is amazing what he can do with his writing. Chris proves to Gordy how good of a friend he is by encouraging him to apply himself and that he wants the best for him.As the four boys, Chris, Gordy, Teddy, and Vern are on the trip they find out a little more about reality. They begin to realize that you can do anything if you apply yourself. Even if you don't have your parents who don't believe in you, you have at least one friend who does. That would be your best friend. The time of day and the soundtracks throughout the move really goes along with the plot line.I would definitely give this movie 10/10 stars. It has life lessons in it and can really show people that life in the 80s wasn't anything like it is now. It's a whole different perspective. It's really neat that it was filmed at that time period too!

Stand by Me is a coming of age film starring Will Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O'Connell. The Movie is based upon the novel by Stephen King, "The Body." Four childhood friends embark on an adventure to find the body of a missing boy. The four friends are different from each other and each have their demons that they are battling. Throughout the film, their issues are unfolded which lead to the choices they make. Will Wheaton plays the lead, Gordie Lachance, a quiet, reserved character who is living in his late brother's shadow and with a resentful father, he bears guilt. River Phoenix plays Chris Chambers, who came from a bad family and is known as a thief. Corey Feldman plays Teddy Duchamp, a known physically abused kid. Jerry O'Connell plays Vern Tessio, the pathetic, easily teased, "fat kid". The editing effectively guides the audiences' thoughts, associations, and emotional responses right from the beginning sequence. In the beginning, we see the storyteller, played by Richard Dreyfuss, sitting in his pickup, looking into the distance as two young teens pedal by on their bicycles. He looks at a news article telling of a person's death. The camera zooms in slow motion focusing in on the expression of Dreyfuss' character who looks deep in thought. The zoom transitions into a start of a flashback as the narrator begins to voice-over the story. This one scene involves a massive amount of editing in such a small amount of time. The music in the background also sets an emotional tone. The kids on bicycles riding by, perhaps foreshadows that the story is about kids that age. And who is the person in the article of the paper? Will we find out? This scene is a great example of smooth continuity and coherence.During the scene at the junk yard, involving Chopper, the infamous, scary, guard dog, sound effects come into play. The invisible dog sound effects are effective. These sound effects of a dog barking evoke a mood and atmosphere of fear for Gordie and the others which creates drama of what's to come next. The camera angle is also focused on Gordie's face and it's only after he makes it safely over the fence that we see that less intimidating Chopper. This same effect reminds me of the scene in the movie, The Sandlot, where a similar effect was achieved. The sound effects along with the filming of the scene creates the mood of suspense right before the object, the dog, is shown. It achieves a greater effect by leaving it to the audience's imagination. The movie is a great coming of age film, riveting, and nostalgic for many. I grew up loving this film at about the same age as the leading characters. I also am a fan of the fantastic soundtrack that was included in the plot line.

Review title: An amazing, realistic and nostalgic experience.
Review_body: I haven't read Stephen King's novel and I wasn't really sure if I was going to like this movie or not. My expectations were high, though. And it turned out to be one of my favorite movies of all time! The first thing that shocks you and leaves you speechless is the maturity of the main actors. Their acting seems to be so real, so down-to-earth and yet fascinating. I am not much of an emotional person and I do not often cry over movies, because there is always an inner voice telling me: This is not real, this is art, it is supposed to be entertainment. But this... It just hit me as hard as it could, I found myself with tears filling my eyes even the day after watching it. I am only 17, and I know that life is ahead of me, but for some reason it just made me feel nostalgic and old. It made me somehow regret watching it, but at the same time I want to watch it over and over again. I am not a movie expert, but for me - this was not a movie. This was my childhood, my memories, my desperate wish to turn back time. And maybe some more competent people criticize particular parts of this movie (for example, the main actors smiled in some scenes even though they were supposed to be serious), but for me these "flaws" made this movie perfect and real. They reminded me of me and my squad when we were that age, our pointless conversations, fights, joking, crying... For me, this movie is by far the best picture of that innocent stage in our lives. And a raw reminder that you'll never be that young and free again. But there are memories that help us. Memories - and things like this movie.

Review title: Stand by Me was a movie that truly blew me out of my socks.
Review_body: Stand by Me was a movie that truly blew me out of my socks. I saw it first when I was very young and I thought it was great, but completely forgot about it. Over the years, I thought less and less about it until I came across it again one day. I popped it in to see what I had forgotten about, and I found myself crying more than once. It sent a message that children should be receiving very early on. It's a movie about friendship and loyalty. I think my favorite scene was the 'Milk Money' scene. I found myself crying with Christopher Chambers about his dramatic loss and how everyone thought nothing of the 'low-life Chambers kid.' This movie is essentially about four boys looking towards one goal. To be a hero by finding the missing body of Ray Brower and to be redeemed in their town's eyes. And when they set out on their 2-day trek, they learn things about each other that they never knew before. They learn that in each other's eyes they're all equal, and that's all that matters. They learn that they don't need to be redeemed in each other's eyes, because all of them have enough issues with themselves to be able to worry about the issues they have with their friends. But when the rival gang sets out with the same goal and they meet in that last scene, the whole movie pulls together to its ultimate climax. And this group of boys makes for a fun, dramatic and hilarious movie. Teddy Duchamp and Chris Chambers, both doomed to a life of misery by their deranged or angry fathers. Vern Tessio, the sacredly cat with a brother in their rival gang, and Gordie Lachance, perhaps one of my favorite characters in this movie, and the narrator. Gordie is the sensitive writer who just wants a little love from his parents after his brother died in a jeep accident. He was one of the characters that made me cry most, along with Chris.Chris and Gordie are the best of friends, which is something that I think sends out a good message as well. Having a best friend whose shoulder you can cry on and who will always try to be there with you if you ever, in slightly dramatic terms, have a mental breakdown. This movie is highly recommended. Definitely worth seeing, as it has turned into one of my favorites. Especially that one last line:'I never had friends later on in life like the ones I had when I was twelve. Jesus, does anybody?'

Stand By Me is a great film about kids, and the adventures and troubles they get into. Stand By Me showcases all of them, wrapped in drama, sadness, and humor. Stand By Me is a great film to have under your belt. Wil Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O'Connell work so well together, it's like they've always been friends. And together, with Keifer Sutherland, it makes a fantastic group. Not to mention director Rob Reiner, he knows how to direct, because he has been directed. "all In The Family" wouldn't be the same if it wasn't for Michael "Meathead" Stivick (SP). Anyways, back to Stand By Me. Fantastic. Good for anyone to watch. 10 Stars for this coming-of-age flick!

Stand By Me is a great film. It has received a 91% on Rotten Tomatoes, 8.1 on IMDb, and praises from many people. It is a quiet little film that evokes wonder through marvelous plot twists, humor inside fascinating characters, and mystery in deepening pools of trouble. The director of the film, Rob Reiner, created a perfect film to go along with Stephen King's novel, The Body. The book came out in 1982 and the movie came out four years later in 1986, but this legendary film still captures the hearts of many today. Aside from being compared to other big hitters such as The Outsiders, The Lost Boys, Goonies, and many more, it stands out as it's own beautiful film. In this captivating movie, four best friends set out to find the body of a dead boy. They dodge trains, walk through leech filled marshes, argue with a junk yard man, and tumble with a rowdy gang who want to find the body for themselves. The gang is filled with some older brothers of the four boys and Ace, the meanest of the group. Their big battle for the grand prize all started because of chubby, noisy, and hysterical Vern. Vern (Jerry O'Connell) is looking for his lost coins under the porch when his older brother and one of the gang members walk up the porch steps and start talking about where the body of Ray Brower, aka dead boy, is. Vern listens and eventually escapes from the porch and runs to tell his friends in their fort. After hearing the story, they decide to start their journey across the train tracks that night. For one person in this story, Gordie LaChance (Wil Wheaton) this isn't just another adventure, it's personal. Ever since his older brother,Denny (John Cusack), died Gordie's parents haven't been the same, and he thinks it's because they had to see their dead son. Gordie will do anything he can to try and understand what happened, and he will stop at nothing to see the deceased Ray Brower. Just like Gordie won't stop until he see's a dead body, Rob Reiner won't stop until he creates a masterpiece. Even though this movie is based on a book, Rob put his own spin on things. For example, in the book Gordie and Teddy (Corey Feldman) fight about trying to dodge a train, but in the movie it's Chris (River Phoenix) who fights with him. In the book Gordie has a vision of his older brother, Denny, telling him that he should be in the casket instead of him. While in the movie Gordie has a dream of his father (Marshall Bell), telling him he should be dead instead of Denny. These are very minor changes that don't affect the plot. Overall Rob did a great job of following the book. This movie is about overcoming obstacles and evolving friendship. This can be shown in a multiple number of scenes. An example of this is when they find the body and talk about what to do next. While they are discussing this, the older boys show up and torment them. Ace pulls a knife and threatens to hurt all the boys if they didn't give Ace and the gang credit for finding the body. Ace grabs Chris and puts the knife to his throat. At this point, Chris' big brother Eyeball Chambers (Bradley Gregg) starts trying to get Ace to stop. While this is going on, Gordie grabs a hidden gun, that Chris stashed in his sleeping bag, and fires it straight up in the air. He tells Ace to let him go and to leave. Ace then challenges him by saying "What are you going to do? Shoot us all?" , so Gordie cocks the gun and says "No, Ace. Just You." That is enough to make Ace stand down and leave with the rest of the gang. The boys then decide to place an anonymous tip to the police. They all stuck together and overcame the biggest obstacle they had faced. Unfortunately all good things must come to an end. "It happens sometimes. Friends come in and out of our lives, like busboys in a restaurant." Just like this movie eventually had to end, so did the friendships. In the end, Gordie reveals how all of these friendships ended up, whether it was naturally growing apart, or being ripped away by things we can't control. Gordie tells us that throughout the years, Vern and Teddy grew apart from Chris and Gordie. They would say hello in the hallways, but other than that, they became a person in a sea of people. Vern went on to be quite successful in life, but unfortunately Teddy did the opposite. He got rejected by the military because of his terrible eyesight and started working odd jobs around town. Chris and Gordie stayed good friends throughout life, but their marvelous friendship ended tragically. Chris was at a fast food restaurant when one of the men in line pulled a knife on another. Chris tried to make peace between the two men but he ended up taking one to the jugular and died on the spot. Gordie grew up to be a writer with a family. Rob ends the movie perfectly by having Gordie at the computer writing out "I never had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve. Jesus, does anyone?" Overall this is a great movie with a fantastic message.The director does an amazing job and the acting is superb. I would recommend this movie to everyone. Whether you're into action, drama, or heartbreak, this movie has it all.

Review title: HELLO? if you've never seen this movie, man you're missin OUT!
Review_body: I am 14 years old, and I absolutely love this movie. But don't let my age fool you. I'm not just going to sit here and talk about how hott River Pheonix was.This movie is well rounded in my perspective. Everyone can relate to at least one of the boys in it at one time in their life. The actors are matched perfectly with who their character portrays.Corey Feldman's character Teddy is the boy who's sensitive about his dad, but tries to hide it, Jerry O' Connell's character Vern is the chubby, wussy kid, but still part of the club, Wil Wheaton's character Gordie is the sweet, intelligent friend who tells stories to the other boys and is ignored by his parents, and River Phoenix's character Chris is the boy in the neighborhood that's been labeled a bad kid and feels he'll never get out of their town, the peacemaker, and Gordie's best friend. This movie just sucks you in as soon as you start watching it. It's not overly mushy and sad, but it's not so tough that only a sixteen year old boy could stand it. You feel for each character, no matter how mean or nice they are. My personal favorite is Chris Chambers, which i know this will probably drive you guys nuts that almost every other person does too, but River Phoenix is just so touching. The campfire scene is great, the milk money seen is great, and one of my favorites is the train scene. You can definitely see the terror in their faces. It's funny that they all act so tough, except maybe Vern, although he tries, and they still like talking about goofy and dancing and singing along to Lollipop. You also just want to be there with them. Feel that kind of friendship that so many people long for. It's such a feel good movie, but not in the sense of a 10 year old's feel good movie. It makes you feel complete when you watch it. It's not jam packed with action sequences or it doesn't have fluffy pink bunnies hopping around in it either. It's just one of a kind. Definitely worth my time and yours.The newest DVD of Stand By Me (Special Edition) has Walking the Tracks: The Summer of Stand By Me where all the main actors,except River, and Rob Reiner are interviewed. They also talk about working with River Phoenix. There's also the Stand By Me music video with River Phoenix, Wil Wheaton, and obviously Ben E. King. Not to mention an extra CD with some awesome oldie's songs like Everyday, Lollipop, Stand By Me, and Mr. Lee.

After the death of his friend, a grown-up Gordie, now a writer, recounts a childhood journey. Gordie and three friends travel a long way to see the body of dead boy, and have several adventures on the way. I thought this movie was excellent. I thought it was a really nice, simple, unpretentious movie with themes that were really great, and really relevant. The characters, and some of the actors playing them, were amazing. River Phoenix stood out especially, he was a fantastic actor for his age, but the same applies to the other child actors; they brought the characters to life so well. I felt like I knew them all so well, and I suppose I do have friends, or know someone just like each of the characters. Although the characters were great, the one criticism I have about them is that they were a bit cliché and stereotyped. For example, the quiet artistic child whose brother died and whose father hates him. Or the fat, loser, woosey boy. But I suppose the characters are like that so we do relate and feel like we know each one of the characters. Apart from that, everything else was great. It wasn't too long or too short, and the story never seemed to lag. It's funny, hilarious even at times, but it's still touching, and sweet. The filmmakers and the actors manage to capture every aspect of childhood without being one of those awful, lovely, candy-coated, happy, Hollywood movies. The movie makes me feel lucky that I'm still young, and that I still can make the most of my life, but at the same time, it made me wish I was 12 again, that I was still innocent, and had friends like Vern and Gordie and Chris.

Stand by Me is so realistic that it captures you and draws you in. It is a feel good film even though I wish that Chris didn't die in the film, I thought it was a sad way to finish a fantastic film. I hope in the future that another film will be made that is as good as Stand by Me. But I doubt it!

Review_body: Luckily that I had good enough friends and so much memories for this masterpiece to make sense.

I was 16 in 1986, not long older than Chris, Gordie, Teddy and Vern.I remember the long hot summers with months off school, Our gang going on expeditions to the park, canals, the local woods or any one of the places we adventured "all which needed miles of rail track to follow" I first watched Stand by me in 1986 and it was good then, because I watched it with the mates I had when I was twelve. Since then I've seen what a revelation it truly is. This film has more than just a story line, it is now also sadly poignant, relating to River Phoenix. Also it comes from the pen of the genius Stephen King. The novella it came from also contained the Shawshank redemption and Apt Pupil both of which became hit films.A film for anyone who has forgotten their roots, or 12 an over.I was going to give 10/10 but how can you judge this film against others as it so unique. so I give it 100,000,000/10
